title: royal news queen elizabeth ii stopped charles marrying princess diana law spt
story: The pressures of a royal marriage&nbspare there for all to see as it is&nbspa union in which there is an element of public ownership in addition to private commitment. Princess Margaret was persuaded not to marry the orced Peter Townsend, in 1978, however, she was at length permitted to orce Lord Snowdon. Having said that,&nbspMargaret was never heir to the throne, nor ever likely to be after Charles&rsquo birth in 1948.                Prince William's FURIOUS phone call to Princess Diana revealed                Princess Diana's FURIOUS confrontation with Camilla REVEALEDThe Prince saw it as a happy precedent when his sister, Princess Anne married a commoner, Captain Mark Philips, in 1973.Though, Princess Anne was freer to choose, with her three brothers between her and the throne.In &ldquoCharles, Prince of Wales by Anthony Holden, the author reveals how the Queen once wanted to abolish the Royal Marriages Act in favour of Prince Charles having more freedom with his marriage plans.Had she been successful, the history books could have been rewritten as Charles would have hypothetically been free to marry Camilla Parker Bowles prior to his engagement to Princess Diana.The book, published in 1979, explains that it is possible that in Elizabeth II&rsquos lifetime, we may see the repeal of both the laws restricting royal choice.Prince Charles kisses Princess Diana's hand at their wedding in 1981 (Image: )Charles and Diana's wedding was initially dubbed a 'fairytale' (Image: )The Queen wanted to change royal precedent regarding marriage (Image: )Mr Holden&nbspwrote:&nbsp&ldquoThe Queen has it in mind to persuade a Prime Minister to do away with the Royal Marriages Act.According to the author, the &ldquoRoyal Marriages Act has long outlived it&rsquos purpose.George III introduced it in an attempt to curb his son&rsquos erratic sexual behaviour, and thus ensured that it affected all those in direct line of succession.In 1978, therefore, the sixteenth in line, Prince Michael of Kent, had to renounce all rights to the throne to wed a Roman Catholic, Baroness Marie-Christine von Reibnitz, whose previous marriage was annulled.The Pope refused them permission to marry in a church, which prompted the Prince of Wales to make a bold public protest about the &ldquoneedless distress caused by doctrinal dispute among Christians.The Prince saw it as a happy precedent when Princess Anne married a commoner, Captain Mark Philips (Image: Getty)The pressures of a royal marriage was there for all to see (Image: Getty)But the act had already been proved unrealistic, in the latter half of the twentieth century, by Princess Margaret&rsquos orce, and the orce and remarriage of the Queen&rsquos cousin, the Earl of Harewood.In November last year, Prince Harry shared his plans to marry American actress Meghan Markle with the public, but it wasn't until March 15, 2018 that their engagement became&nbspofficial.That is&nbspwhen Queen Elizabeth II released a statement giving her formal consent for the couple to wed.Without it, their marriage would have been considered invalid under a British law that dates back to the 18th century.The&nbsp1772 Royal Marriages Act stated that all marriages to a member of the British royal family were subject to the approval of the reigning monarch.The statute read:&nbspEvery&nbspmarriage, or matrimonial contract, of any such descendant, without such consent first had and obtained, shall be null and void to all intents and purposes whatsoever.This rule received an update in 2013 with the passing of the Succession to the Crown Act. Today, only the first six royals in line to the throne require the monarch's permission to validate their marriages.&nbspMeghan Markle and Prince Harry would not have been able to marry without Queen's consent (Image: Getty)The Queen shares a joke with Meghan Markle (Image: )That means that for Prince Harry&nbsp&ndash&nbspwho was fifth in line when he announced his engagement, but knocked into sixth place in April with the birth of His Royal Highness Prince Louis of Cambridge&nbsp&ndash&nbspgetting&nbspthe Queen's&nbspblessing was vital.&nbspThe Succession to the Crown Act became relevant this year when Prince William and Kate Middleton welcomed baby Prince Louis into their family.&nbspUnder the old laws, the birth of a boy would have bumped Princess Charlotte down a peg in the line of succession, but thanks to the new act she's the first female royal to maintain her spot over a younger male sibling.

title: Brexit news update Jacob Rees Mogg Theresa May deal UK Parliament Brexit vote
story: Speaking to TalkRADIO's Julia Hartley-Brewer, the Conservative backbencher claimed leaving without a deal is nothing to be frightened of and that a no-deal Brexit was still a better solution against Theresa May's deal. Mr Rees-Mogg claimed Brexiteers in the Cabinet should vote against the deal, despite refraining from resigning from their posts, as it would be difficult to maintain their eurosceptic positions if they supported the Prime Minister.                CNN host SAVAGES Alastair Campbell &ndash 'second vote will RIP UK apart'He said: The Prime Minister promised completely different things, then she said no-deal was better than a bad deal. This is a really bad deal, and now she's saying no-deal is quite frightening, he said.Leaving without a deal is nothing to be frightened of.Mr Rees-Mogg added that he would be very surprised if people were gullible enough to support the deal, which will be voted on in the House of Commons on December 11.He said: &ldquoI haven&rsquot spoken to any of them recently... should they resign now?Brexit news: Jacob Rees-Mogg warns Brexiteers in the Cabinet to vote May's deal down (Image: &bullSKY)I think December 11 is the key test, and it would be very hard to say at the end of December 11 that you're a Brexiteer if you vote in favour of this deal.Theresa May's deal is expected to undergo parliamentary scrutiny on December 11.&nbspThe deal has so far received criticism from both sides of the Brexit debate and all sides of the UK Parliament political spectrum.&nbspUp to 91 Tory MPs are presumed to be voting against the Prime Minister's deal in December.The Labour Party, the SNP and the DUP have all confirmed they will vote against the deal in bloc.&nbspHowever, on Monday, Theresa May&rsquos chief of staff Gavin Barwell mounted a charm offensive to woo Labour MPs into backing her deal.Mr Barwell called on the opposition to ride to the Prime Minister&rsquos rescue and get her deal through the Commons.He was adamant the withdrawal agreement was the best deal that's available.Mr Barwell said: That's a judgement for you to make. But the Prime Minister believes this is the best deal that's available.

title: brexit news theresa may brexit deal british exports uk latest
story: The Prime Minister is due to fly to Scotland this afternoon to claim the fishing industry and other food producers can benefit under continuing close trade links with the EU promised under her agreement with Brussels.&nbspShe will also insist that the deal will also mean exporters can find new markets after the UK negotiates new trade treaties with countries around the world. But her attempt to sell her Brexit deal to the country suffered a fresh blow when a former close ally condemned it as the worst of all worlds.                May hits back at Trump after US condemns Brexit deal                Johnson challenges May with &lsquosomeone who BELIEVES in Brexit'Former defence secretary Sir Michael Fallon confirmed he planned to vote against the deal in a crunch Commons vote on December 11.He said: My fear is that this deal gives us the worst of all worlds - no guarantee of smooth trade in the future and no ability to reduce the tariffs that we need to conclude trade deals with the rest of the world.So, unless the House of Commons can be persuaded somehow that those are possible, then I think, yes, the deal is doomed.Mrs May is due to speak to employees at a factory near Glasgow today on the final leg of her tour of the UK to promote her deal ahead of a crunch vote by MPs on December 11.She is expected to say: It is a deal that is good for Scottish employers and which will protect jobs. It includes a new free trade area with no tariffs, fees, quantitative restrictions or rules of origin checks&mdashan unprecedented economic relationship that no other major economy has.At the same time, we will be free to strike our own trade deals around the world &ndash providing even greater opportunity to Scottish exporters. I welcome the strong support which employers have given to the deal and the certainty which it provides.British Prime Minister Theresa May (Image: )Crucially, the deal also ensures that we will leave EU programmes that do not work in our interests. So we will be out of the common agricultural policy, which has failed our farmers, and out of the common fisheries policy, which has so tragically failed Scotland&rsquos coastal communities.At long last, we will be an independent coastal state again &ndash taking back full sovereign control over our waters, and free to decide for ourselves who we allow to fish in our waters.The EU maintained throughout the negotiation process that it wanted to link overall access to markets to access to fisheries.It failed in the withdrawal agreement and it failed again in the political declaration.I have been robust in defending the interests of Scottish fisherman so far and I will always be so.Mrs May will argue that her deal will a free trade area for goods with no tariffs, fees or charges that will benefit British firms.She will also say that the deal delivers for Scottish fishermen by taking back control of our waters.                Sturgeon says May&rsquos &rsquoUNACCEPTABLE' deal will make Scotland poorerMrs May is due to speak to employees at a factory near Glasgow today (Image: Liam McBurney - WPA PoolGetty Images)Downing Street officials pointed to support for the deal from leading Scottish businesses and business organisations including drinks giant Diageo, National Farming Union Scotland, the Scotch Whisky Association and BAE Systems.On her tour on Tuesday, Mrs May talked to business leaders gathered at Queen's University in Belfast.We need to do it in a way that protects jobs and protects our good access to the EU markets, she said.Earlier, she toured the Royal Welsh Winter Fair in Builth Wells, Powys.The Brexit deal has been agreed and I am taking that to the House of Commons, she said during the visit.I am here today at the winter fair at the Royal Welsh hearing from farmers and manufacturers the importance of the certainty that the deal brings, the importance of the free trade area and the ability to continue to export well with the European Union in the future, which we see in that Political Declaration for our future relationship on trade with the European Union.I think what is important when MPs come to vote is that they think about the national interest - that means delivering on Brexit but it means doing it in a way that delivers for people in protecting their security, protecting their jobs, protecting their livelihoods. This deal delivers on both of those.Mrs May was braced for a further backlash from Tory Eurosceptics today when the Treasury publishes an economic analysis of the potential costs and benefits of Mrs May's Brexit deal in comparision with staying in the EU or leaving without a deal.Former Brexit minister Steve Baker said: &ldquoThe reputation of government economics is in the gutter. That must change. It&rsquos time for the Chancellor to publish all his assumptions and full model documentation so we can begin the process of recovery.Former Cabinet minister Priti Patel said: &ldquoWe&rsquove all had about enough of Project Fear.&ldquoWe were told during the referendum campaign that we&rsquod each lose &pound4,300 and that there would be a recession and higher unemployment.&nbsp And yet we&rsquove seen record wage growth and record employment levels.&ldquoIf ministers spent time preparing for a no deal scenario, rather than dreaming up silly scare stories, we could all make a success of our post-Brexit future.&ldquoIt&rsquos time our Government started betting on and believing in Britain. Let&rsquos be optimistic &ndash we have a great future ahead of us.

story: Gu&ethlaugur &THORN&oacuter &THORN&oacuter&etharson said he welcomed the idea of the UK joining the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) or the European Economic Area (EEA). He used the example of Iceland, which is in EFTA and the EEA, so makes use of those trade deals but can also make is own deals with the rest of he world. Mr &THORN&oacuter&etharson, who is from the Icelandic liberal-conservative eurosceptic Independence Party, said there is no appetite in his country to be members of the EU or the customs union. story: Labour report proposes new laws for UK business to reduce inequality (Image: )As well as customers, employees and shareholders of the top 7,000 companies in the UK would also be given a right to decide whether the bosses' pay should be capped. The recommendation came out of a report commissioned by Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell and Shadow Business Secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey, who welcomed the idea. The report, drawn up by Prem Sikka, professor of accountancy and finance at Sheffield University, argues inequality is exacerbated by boardroom excesses.                BACK BREXIT: May's chief BEGS Labour MPs to get behind her deal                Brexiteer brilliantly dismantles Labour MP claim in fiery Brexit clashThe report adds that the wealth created by the &ldquobrawn and brains of employees being hoarded at the top is a &ldquokey social problem.Mr McDonnell said: &ldquoThe scale of bonuses and the opaque way they are paid should be a source of shame to those running out country.&ldquoThe Government have shown no interest in tackling the causes of inequality in our society and we are grateful to Professor Sikka and his team for shining a light on the problem.As well as the votes on pay caps, the report suggests executive pay be made publicly available, as well as the difference between executive and employees pay, taking into account gender and ethnicity.Shadow Business Secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey (Image: )These new laws would also enforce cash rewards only for executive as shares and perks &ldquoinvite abuses.The report states: &ldquoThe challenge is not only to devise mechanisms that constrain undeserved executive pay in large companies but also create mechanisms to enable workers to secure an equitable share of incomewealth created by their own brain, brawn, sweat, commitment and energy.&ldquoCustomers are the backbone of all enterprises but are increasingly being poorly treated through profiteering by banks, gas, water, electricity and other companies.&ldquoThey should be empowered to penalise executives delivering poor goodsservice quality and equally also reward those delivering high quality products and services.                Starmer ROASTED by Sky News host as he claims he could do betterLabour wants to cut down boardroom excess (Image: )Ms Long-Bailey slammed the &ldquocorporate culture in some firms as &ldquoimmoral.She said: &ldquoWhilst many of our business work hard to ensure that rewards and prosperity are faired shared across the workforce, there continues to exist a pernicious corporate culture in some firms that many across Britain would view as immoral.&ldquoIt cannot be right that in just three working days, the UK&rsquos top bosses will have made more money than the typical full-time worker will earn in the entire year.&ldquoLabour will look closely at the recommendations of this report as we seek to build on our existing policy of tackling pay inequality.

title: Stone of Destiny Perth Edinburgh Castle
story: The Stone of Scone &ndash Perth wants it from Edinburgh (Image: The Print CollectorPrint CollectorGetty)Perth and Kinross Council is lobbying for it to be housed at a new &pound20million arts hub.&nbspCouncillors want it returned after a 700-year absence to be the centrepiece at the new-look city hall due to open in 2021. But authorities at Edinburgh Castle want the stone to stay as part of their own collection. The royally-appointed Commissioners of the Regalia have received pleas from both Perth and Kinross Council, and Edinburgh Castle for the stone. The commissioners were made responsible for the safe-keeping of the artefact if it needs to be taken to Westminster Abbey for any future coronation. Any move will ultimately be ruled on by the Queen.Charles Kinnoull, the chairman of Culture at Perth and Kinross, said: &ldquoHaving the stone at Edinburgh Castle means visitors have to pay to see it. We want to bring it to Perth so that it is freely available to everyone.                Sturgeon says May&rsquos &rsquoUNACCEPTABLE' deal will make Scotland poorer                Theresa May in DESPERATE bid to win over Scots to her Brexit dealIt is thought to have been taken by England&rsquos Edward I in 1296 and placed in Westminster Abbey (Image: Universal History ArchiveUIG via Getty)&ldquoAny proposal regarding the Stone of Destiny would be a matter for the Commissioners of the Regalia, as per the 1996 Royal Warrant, a spokesman said.The Scottish Government confirmed that proposals regarding the Stone of Destiny from Perth and Kinross Council and Historic Environment Scotland were being considered by the commissioners.Perth and Kinross Council announced its plan to reclaim the Stone of Destiny in June, 2016. The stone was at Scone for hundreds of years and was used as the throne on which the kings of Scotland were anointed.&nbspIt is thought to have been taken by England&rsquos Edward I in 1296 and placed in Westminster Abbey, where it was incorporated into England&rsquos coronation throne. However, some believe that the stone taken by Edward was a fake.The stone was famously stolen by four nationalist Glasgow University students on Christmas Day in 1950 and left, draped in a Scottish flag, at Arbroath Abbey.&nbspIt was recovered by police and returned to Westminster in time for the Queen&rsquos coronation in 1953. On St Andrew&rsquos Day 1996, the stone was finally returned to Scotland. It has remained on display in Edinburgh Castle ever since.

story: In the latest tirade in his ongoing war of words with Brussels, Italy&rsquos Deputy Prime Minister raged someone at the European Union &ldquohas obviously done something wrong if a country as important as Britain can exit the bloc. The UK is currently the fifth largest economy in the world and the second largest behind Germany in Europe with annual GDP of &pound2.1 trillion. But the Brexit process will see Britain exit the bloc - with our without a deal - on March 29, 2019 before entering a proposed 21-month transition period until the end of December 2020.                Italy to BACKTRACK on budget? Salvini hints Rome COULD bow to EU                Italy says it WILL stick to budget for nowOn Sunday, the UK and EU agreed the text for the Withdrawal Agreement following a specially arranged summit of the remaining EU27 leaders in Brussels.But speaking to Italian news agency Adnkronos, Matteo Salvini said: If people vote, the result must always be respected, but Europe now needs self-examination because, in any case, Great Britain was one of the countries that had the most advantages as part of the Union and it kept its own currency.&ldquoSo if a country as important as them has decided to exit the EU, someone in Brussels has obviously done something wrong.READ MORE: BREXIT LIVE - &lsquoShe has GIVEN UP!&rsquo May CONDEMNED by furious Foster - &lsquoWe NEED a better way&rsquoBrexit news: Matteo Salvini has reignited his war of words with the EU (Image: )Mr Salvini said he had held talks with Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte and Foreign Affairs Minister Enzo Moavero over how Italy can move forward after Brexit and protect hundreds of thousands of Italians living and working in Britain.He added: &ldquoWhat interests me now is to protect the 700 thousand Italians who are there and the Italian companies that work in the UK.&ldquoThey made their choice and it was right to support them.This latest attack comes after he and Deputy Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio reiterated they will not bow to EU pressure over its budget plan for 2019, despite earlier hinting at a softened stance.The Italian government vowed to stick to its main spending goals for next year while awaiting for a cost analysis of its spending measures.                EU hits back at Italy in budget CLASH - &lsquoI am NOT Santa Claus!&rsquo                Tajani WARNS 'isolated' Italy to change budget or 'suffer' consequenceBrexit news: Matteo Salvini is focused in protecting the 700,000 Italians living in Britain (Image: )But Rome insisted it remains open to the idea of eventually lowering the controversial deficit target and keeping dialogue open with EU chiefs, who have already rejected the fiscal plans and accused Italy of breaching spending commitments.Mr Conte, Mr Salvini and Mr Di Maio, met yesterday to discuss the budget and potential disciplinary action from Brussels.They said in a joint statement: &ldquoThe objectives that have already been fixed are confirmed.&ldquoAs far as the on-going discussions with European institutions are concerned, we agreed to wait for the technical analysis of the proposed reforms which have the most important social impact to quantify precisely the cost.Mr Salvini suggested Rome could be braced to back down to EU demands as he declared the deficit target, which is currently set at 2.4 percent for next year, could be moved.Italy budget: The government has vowed to stick to its main spending goals for 2019 (Image: )He said: &ldquoI think nobody is fixated on this, if there is a budget which makes the country grow, it could be 2.2 percent or 2.6 percent.&ldquoThe problem is not about decimal points, it&rsquos a question of seriousness and being concrete.Italy&rsquos latest defiant stance comes as European Commissioner for Economic Affairs Pierre Moscovici suggested he was open to further negotiation over the controversial budget.Speaking at a press conference in Paris, he said: I have never been a partisan of sanctions, I think sanctions are always a failure. I have always been in favour of flexibility.Italy budget: Pierre Moscovici maintained the spending plans pose huge risks (Image: )He added the door remains open and the hand outstretched to Italy, and continued: We must seek with all our strength shared solutions in the interest of Italians and the eurozone.But Mr Moscovici made clear this shouldn&rsquot been seen as a softening of its stance on Italy&rsquos budget, which it still sees as extremely high risk to an economy already with the second largest debt in the eurozone behind Greece.He said: We continue to think that the Italian budget entails risks for companies, investors and Italian citizens.&ldquoThis risk has a name: it is called debt at 130 percent of GDP.Additional reporting by Maria Ortega.

title: Michael Schumacher health latest schumacher statement formula 1 news
story: The German legend&rsquos health has been a closely guarded secret every since he suffered catastrophic brain injuries in a skiing accident in 2013. She said she and his wife Corinna were &ldquoprotecting his wishes to keep his condition secret because Mr Schumacher was a &ldquoprivate inidual.Ms Kehm told how it was the driving ace&rsquos &ldquosecret dream to be able to &ldquodisappear.She said: &ldquoIn general the media have never reported on Michael and Corinna's private life.&ldquoWhen he was in Switzerland, for example, it was clear he was a private inidual.Once in a long discussion Michael said to me: 'You don't need to call me for the next year, I'm disappearing.'Michael Schumacher health latest: The F1 driver's has revealed why his health is a secret  (Image:  )Michael Schumacher's manager says the driving legend was 'private' (Image:  )I think it was his secret dream to be able to do that some day.That's why now I still want to protect his wishes in that I don't let anything get out.It comes after Ms Kehm broke her silence earlier this month to issue a rare emotional statement to celebrate the Formula 1 racing legend&rsquos iconic record on the track.Michael Schumacher&rsquos manager spoke after a poster was unveiled to commemorate his iconic career, released in cooperation with the racing legend&rsquos Keep Fighting Foundation.                Michael Schumacher&rsquos son CLOSER to following in father's footstepsMichael Schumacher was injured in a horror skiing accident  (Image:  )On behalf of the Schumacher family, Ms Kehm said: We are delighted to be partnering with ZOOM to raise money for the Keep Fighting Foundation.&ldquoThis is a stunning way to celebrate Michael's iconic career and by the way a very beautiful poster.Schumacher's career saw him amass a record seven world titles and the most amount of wins (91) ever for a driver.The German driver was placed in a medically induced coma for nearly six months but then in June 2014 was discharged from hospital and has since been receiving medical care at home near Lake Geneva in Switzerland.Michael Schumacher&rsquos medical bills are said to cost &pound115,000 a week from a team of 15 nurses and physicians.The racing legend has reportedly been left paralysed following the tragic ski accident but those claims are unconfirmed.

title: what brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border latest
story: Heres our guide to the plan and what it means for Northern Ireland and its border with the Republic of Ireland.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.The backstop will see Britain remain in the customs union for as long as necessary until an alternative way of keeping the border open is found.Mrs May wants the UK to have the right to end the backstop at will - but the EU has warned that would render the mechanism pointless.It would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.At the same time the UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries.On November , thereported that Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab demanded the right to pull Britain out of the EU’s Irish backstop after just three months.The paper claimed the hardline pitch to the Irish government “stunned” officials.Its claimed Mr Raab’s proposal was put to the Irelands deputy prime minister Simon Coveney in a private meeting in London.However, the Irish Prime Minister told Theresa May that he will not accept a Brexit deal which gives the UK the unilateral power to halt backstop arrangements for the border with Northern Ireland.The EU has suggested a backstop that would see Northern Ireland staying in the customs union, the EU VAT system and parts of the single market.This will essentially draw a customs border down the middle of the Irish Sea, potentially damaging the union of the UK.Mrs May has suggested a backstop that will see all of the UK aligned with the EU customs union for a limited time after .Brussels has two issues with Mays plan.The first is that May wants the backstop to come to an end after a certain time period the EU thinks this would be self-defeating as its possible no solution for the Irish border would be found.The EU also thinks this risks leaving Britain benefiting from the customs union and single market for years after Brexit - reaping all the benefits without having any of the obligations that full membership would entail.In June  European leaders said Britain was running out of time to do a deal because of the unsolved border problem.In July Theresa May quoted Shakespeare as she insisted the UK would not be broken up with a border down the Irish Sea.Theresa May has told EU leaders she is looking at ways of keeping Britain under their rules for at least another year as part of efforts to break the Brexit deadlock.Addressing the  national bosses at a tense summit in Brussels on the night of October , the PM said she is “ready to consider” extending the  month transition period after the UK leaves the EU next March.The potentially incendiary move has been drawn up by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier to try to end a bitter impasse over the Irish border.It would mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest.The news comes after talks on Sunday, October , hit a brick wall once again, as the issue of the Irish border continues to cause a headache for Theresa May.Theresa May has insisted any backstop arrangement must apply to the UK as a whole so not to create a border in the Irish Sea.However, talks broke down after the EU had insisted on a second backstop arrangement - just involving Northern Ireland -the UKs version wasnt ready in time, according to Downing Street sources.Brussels admitted in a draft trade agreement that technology COULD be used to solve the thorny issue of the border, using Max Fac solutions at the frontier as part of a future deal between the UK and EU.But the backstop - which keeps Britain in the customs unionno alternative is agreed to keep the Irish border open - will stay in the withdrawal agreement as an insurance policy.Ex-leader Iain Duncan Smith said: The withdrawal agreement will make it very clear that should we struggle with a negotiation for a free trade arrangement and not complete that process, we will fall into the Northern Ireland backstop.I would hope that she would now consider that none of this is at all workable unless we get the withdrawal agreement now amended so that any arrangements we make strip out that backstop.Former minister Owen Paterson added: As long as the backstop is in existence in a legally binding document, there is a danger that should talks fail the backstop becomes accepted.We would have the horror of falling into a customs union, the horror of having Northern Ireland separated from the rest of the United Kingdom.Mrs May dubbed the continuing row with Brussels over how to avoid a hard border in Ireland as “the one real sticking point left, but a considerable one”.The Democratic Unionist Party has vowed to oppose any new checks on goods passing between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.Irelands Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, said that EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier indicated that the European Union will allow extra time for talks about the border.Mr Coveney said he was frustrated and disappointed that it was going to take more time than people had hoped.On November , , the PM faced crunch Cabinet showdowns with her ministers where she will set out the details of the agreement she struck with Brussels the previous day.A number of pro-Brexit ministers are feared to be on the brink of walking out over the deal.They believe it would leave Britain tied to the EU customs union for years to come, because of the controversial Irish backstop arrangement.If the Cabinet does block Mrs Mays deal, she could find her position is untenable - leading to a Tory leadership crisis.

title: get on with brexit corbyn government
story: Well, it has been a very interesting week.The British people — asthey needed further confirmation after what has gone on over the past few months — have been let down by the political class and the establishment elite.The Tories are torn apart by ideology.The party’s historically masterful, pragmatic ability to compromise has disappeared on the one hand and naked political ambition is very evident on the other.Labour has shown total disregard for everyone. Securing a general election is the only thing that matters to them.Jeremy Corbyn is showing scant regard for statesmanship and putting our country’s best interests a poor second to sheer tribal and selfish ambition.I will tell you one thing about Theresa May: No one can say she is putting herself through this for personal political ambition.Hers has been a tormented week of continued public duty and personal, selfless service.Stoic and steadfast, the Prime Minister has shown a resilience seen rarely in politics, probably last admired when another woman ran the country.The stance of Arlene Foster’s DUP is carelessly irresponsible in the extreme.A lot of the “backstop” stuff and the — unacceptable in my view — possibility of the EU being able to block our exit, has been caused by a bona fide effort from May to accommodate the DUP’s wishes.For me, it has been an interesting week in another way as well.I have presided over the board meetings of several of the six private companies I have the honour to chair.Dferent sizes, dferent sectors, dferent parts of the country, yet they are all saying the same things. That business is doing fine. Not what the doomsayers want to hear, but true. It is hard work but certainly not Armageddon.Companies up and down the land are demanding a diet of “boring, stable predictability”. It means they can invest more cash and employ more people. It is uncertainty that kills us.I am hearing from boardrooms that the Brexit proposal is fine, with one big caveat.On the plus side, a Single Market for manufactured goods will work.Anyone selling into the EU — yes, even China and Trump’s USA — has to abide by EU regulation.“Taking it” from Berlin, er, Brussels in this area is not a problem whatever ideologues may say. It secures hundreds of thousands of jobs and tax revenues.The proposed deal means business will be free to recruit essential immigrant labour on the basis of their skill and not where they come from.Choosing from a global, not just an EU, pool of talent is so, so helpful and will assist our international competitiveness hugely.But the one message ringing through my ears is, “Get on with it.”Regardless of whether a business is in Birmingham or Barcelona, Sunderland or Stuttgart, the wealth-creators of Europe, the payers of the tax that builds schools and hospitals, the job-providers just want their politicians to stop this rowing now.Stop the bullying, Berlin stop the rowing, Tories stop the naked, tribal, selfish manoeuvring, Labour — and just do it.One big caveat: You cannot expect anyone in our country — businesswoman or a guy on the line alike — to accept a deal that gives Jean-Claude Juncker’s lot the final say on when, indeed,we leave. Chief negotiator Michel Barnier and his team have bullied us enough.While there are a million dferent beliefs on what the majority of Brits voted for in the referendum, one thing is certain: They DID vote to leave.Giving the EU the final yes no on that is unacceptable and surely no deal is better than that.No deal means no £billion to the unelected, unaccountable Eurocrats. No deal means fewer jobs in troubled Germany and faltering France.Yes, it would be harder for UK business for sure. But not fatal. There would be a price to pay, but whoever said freedom does not come at a price There was one other thing businesses were clear on at my meetings last week.The quicker this country understands there is a greater threat to prosperity, jobs, tax revenues and a successful economy than Brexit, the better.A Corbyn government would turn this country into Venezuela in short order talent and capital would leave so quickly that John McDonnell would have nothing left punitively to tax.The message from small business is as clear as it is strong.The Conservatives, Liberals, big business and the establishment must stop obsessing about Brexit and focus on the greatest threat this country has faced for decades.And that is a bunch of extreme hard-Left business-haters who would ruin this great country and probably blame their abject failure on Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dominic raab rejects theresa mays brexit
story: Despite the unquestionable stamina of our Prime Minister, it is a bad deal for the country and Parliament should reject it.In settling our accounts and paving the way for a future trade agreement, the UK government offered the EU £ billion. The British people will rightly expect a goodon that money.Yet, when it comes to taking back democratic control over our laws, the final terms are worse than membership of the EU.We would still be bound indefinitely by EU-imposed rules on customs, trade, employment, social policy and tax – with no say over those rules, and no ability to exit the regime.The government rightly resisted pressure to accept Free Movement of people from EU countries, to allow us to regain control over our immigration policy.But, the current deal leaves it open for the EU to refuse a permanent trade deal unless we cave in during the second phase of negotiations, after March.As for the dream of a global Britain trading more energetically from Asia to Latin America, the EU has tied our hands, hobbling those ambitions.Much has been made of the Northern Ireland Protocol. No-one wants to see ato the hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland.Instead, the EU’s real game is to try to prise Northern Ireland away from Great Britain, aligning its laws with the EU – a direct threat to the integrity of the UK.Scenting weakness, the EU is now threatening to exclude Gibraltar from a future trade deal.We are being blackmailed and bullied into a flawed deal. The EU has used the negotiations to stle the opportunities and optimism that fired people up to vote Leave in .In truth, there are risks in any course of action we take now. But, by far the gravest is to succumb to the EU’s terms, stay tethered to Brussels, and accept a deal that prevents us from becoming masters of our own destiny.Over the long term, that would drain the strength of our economy, when Brexit should be a boost for workers and consumers. And those who voted Leave would feel cheated, shredding trust in our democracy.Of course, the EU were never going to welcome Brexit. Some sour grapes were inevitable. That’s why we worked hard to leave on positive terms, extending the arm of friendship.In , the EU has taken every concession and gesture of goodwill as a chance to try to bully and control us – at times treating our Prime Minister, and our country, with outright disdain.We need to be honest about the situation: there are risks in a No Deal scenario.But, they can be mitigated and managed by the government -it exercises grip and demonstrates political will. So, let us steel ourselves, and reject this miserly deal.We should make our best final offer to Brussels, then ready ourselves to leave the EU on  March - whatever their response.That way, we can deliver on the verdict of the people, and grasp the opportunities of Brexit. It is time to stand tall in the world, not tremble at the EU’s feet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: low inhaler stock asthma
story: Stocks of Bricanyl Turbohaler inhalers are running low across the country, Asthma UK has warned.Manufacturers of the inhaler have confirmed that there are likely to be a few weeks where stocks arent available at all, the charity said.Bricanyl Turbohaler is an inhaler that contains medicine that relaxes the lungs and airways, helping to manage asthma symptoms.If sufferers are left without vital medicine they are at risk of potentially deadly asthma attacks.Asthma UK said its hard to know how many people might be affected,  but in  some , of the inhalers were prescribed to asthma sufferers.Those who have better control over their symptoms may only need one inhaler a year, the charity said.The manufacturer, AstraZeneca, said it was working as quickly as possible to get its production up and running again.Not all Turbohaler are affected, just stocks of the Bricanyl Turbohaler.Asthma UK is urging all users to check their supply of medicine to make sure they have enough for the coming weeks.If you dont, make an appointment with your GP for an alternative option BEFORE your medication runs out - its vital you arent left without medication.Dont forget to keep taking your preventer inhaler to keep your symptoms at bay.If you can manage your asthma better and keep your airways from becoming inflamed, you’re less likely to need your reliever inhaler - though you shouldn’t try and do without one, make sure you have both types, Dr Whittamore added.Doctors are aware of the supply shortage and will be able to come up with an alternative care plan until the inhaler is available again, Asthma UK said.If you have any questions about how the shortage will affect you you can call Asthma UKs nurses on    or WhatsApp them on   .

title: nasa mars landing scientists handshake
story: Flight controllers in Calornia were shown leaping from their chairs, screaming, clapping and hugging each other after watching their screens intently during a tense seven-minute descent of InSight’s touch-down on the Red Planet.But it was video footage of an intricate series of high and low fist bumps, dance moves and handshakes between two over-the-moon flight controllers that has delighted – and amused – scores of viewers.With the special moment starting an outpouring of tweets and memes, the space agency itself is clearly enjoying the public reaction, asking people to keep the celebrations coming.The InSight lander touched down on Mars just before pm GMT on Monday, surviving the so-called seven minutes of terror, a tricky landing phase for the robotic probe, travelling at ,mph through the planets thin atmosphere which provides little friction to slow down.American space agency Nasas £milliontwo-year mission aims to shine new light on how the Red Planet was formed and its deep structure, by mapping its core, crust and mantle.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jungle gentleman harry redknapp jane moore opinion
story: “I do love her too much andanything happened it would just kill me,” says the former football manager.“We just get on so well. I only want to be with her. I can never wait to see her.”Cue the nation emitting a collective swoon and ’Arry becoming odds-on favourite to take the jungle crown.“Aw, he’s sooooo lovely,” gushed one twentysomething TV commentator, asHarry had just bequeathed all his worldly possessions to help save an endangered species.Given the borderline hysterical response to this “man still loves we after  years” declaration, he might even be considered one himself.But is it really so unusual  To those dating in this Tinder-centric age where people start swiping right the second there’s a minor hiccup, perhaps. But to my generation, less so.Shortly after my Uncle Jack died in his early eighties, my Aunty Mabel announced that she wouldn’t be around for much longer because she couldn’t bear to be without him. Sure enough, she literally lost the will to live and died soon after.It was the same story with my godparents and, as a trainee reporter, I interviewed countless golden wedding coupleswho had endured all manner of marital bumps in the road but lasted the course.How many of today’s liaisons will reach that -year milestone When Harry and Sandra took their vows, they clearly both understood the now largely outdated concept that love is a decision, not just a feeling.In other words, there might have been plenty of niggles and quarrels along the waybut they pushed on through in the knowledge that reaching old age with your spouse and best friend by your side is one of le’s greatest pleasures.The shared experiences, the joy of shared memories, the private jokes, the non-awkward silences and the companionship — bliss.Interestingly, Harry and Sandra’s marital set-up is one that’s increasingly regarded as outdated in this supposedly “progressive” day and age — that of the man bringing home the bacon while the woman runs the house and does the lion’s share of parenting.Consequently, Harry, now , freely admits he can barely make a cup of tea because Sandra does everything for him.It wouldn’t be my, er, cup of tea, but it has worked for them and perhaps it’s because Harry clearly doesn’t view Sandra as “just a housewe”he sees her as the boss and someone whose input he values and respects.And therein lies the key to a happy marriage. It doesn’t matter what the dynamic is as long as each feels appreciated and respected in their chosen role.Harry is what many might consider to be an old-fashioned gentleman, when men were allowed to be one without fear of being branded patronising.He turned away from the female contestants while they were showering and, whenever he gets the chance, awards “the ladies” the rare camp comforts on offer instead of the men.A magnanimous gesture, I notice, that they all accept readily without a passing thought that it might be unfair to the male contestants in these times of supposed equality for both genders.Ashley Roberts danced her bobby socks off in the Lindy hop on Saturday’s Strictly and performed a crackingly good samba too.But she ended up in the bottom two.Why  Because the public never like what they think might be a foregone conclusion.And however much the show tries to dress her up as a plucky amateur, her previous dance experience makes it as implausible as putting Bear Grylls in the I’m A Celebrity “jungle” and seeing him scream at the sight of a cockroach.Remember that moment in Crocodile Dundee when a yob pulls a blade on Mick Dundee in New York and he responds by saying “That’s not a kne”– “that’s a kne”.Fast forward  years and consider the story of Alun Powell, of Newport, Gwent, who takes part in medieval role-playing contests as “Sir Fightalot”.A court heard that when he arrived home to find his father being plagued by a gang outside the house, he pulled a sword, axe and knuckleduster from the boot of his car and “took up a fighting stance”.The prosecution added: “They saw the weapons and got so frightened that they left as quickly as possible.”Job done. End of. Right Nope. Alun ended up in court, convicted of possessing bladed articles in public and given  hours of community service.Perhaps this is why more members of the public don’t get involved when they see trouble.Becausethey don’t have a weapon themselves, they could get hurt.Andthey do happen to have one in their house or car, and brandish it in self-defence, there’s every chance they’ll end up in court themselves while the troublemakers get away scot-free.Robert de Niro is the new face of Warburtons bread.It’s hard to choose my favourite movies starring this acting titan, but Midnight Bun would be top, followed by The Kingsmill Of Comedy and Jackie Brown Bread.Posh store Anthropologie has been ridiculed for selling a bunch of twigs for £.But is the laugh on them or the idiots who buy them In the words of the marvellous Harry Enfield, it must include “we saw you coming” tax.Following on from the debate on whether or not they should have built a ramp to rescue stranded penguins, the crew of BBC’s wildle series Dynasties are in the news again for helping a stricken lion cub.As a rule, those who film such programmes are discouraged from intervening in the events they are trying to capture on the basis that nature should be allowed to take its course.But the cub was shown collapsing and spasming after eating bait laced with poison by tribesmen who had lost their cattle to a lion a few days earlier.So perhaps the new “rule” could be that human intervention is allowed when it’s human intervention that caused the crisis in the first place So how come a -year-old Iranian man – pretending to be  – was blithely placed in a class full of GCSE pupils in Ipswich without so much as a routine dental check Education Secretary Damian Hinds has added to the curriculum certain feats he wants primary school children to achieve before they move up to secondary.He says pupils will be urged to climb trees, explore caves and watch the sun rise to help build character.A good idea, but how depressing that all the things most of us did as a matter of routine in our youth now have to be actively prescribed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: armed forces employment chances research
story: The new study found veteran employment rates are at  per cent – above the national average of . per cent.And it found that  per cent of veterans who said they had a mental health disability were in work compared to just  per cent of civilians battling mental health woes being are in work.The report, conducted by the Veterans Work Consortium titled ‘Veterans Work: Moving On’, surveyed , UK veterans who had left the military in the past  years.Experts who commissioned the report said the figures undermined public perceptions that service le hampers veteran’s chances of getting work when they leave.Chris Recchia, Partner at Deloitte and Chair of the Veterans Work Consortium said: “This data dispels those negative stereotypes.“Our study found veterans are highly employable due to the hard work, determination, flexibility where they work and critically, a willingness to try a whole new career.“Persistent negative stereotypes do unfortunately affect wider societal perception of the veteran community.“It is absolutely true that some veterans have suffered and continue to suffer, this does not reflect the experiences of the majority.”Veterans Work, made-up of leading professional services firm Deloitte, the Armed Forces charity the Officers’ Association and The Forces in Mind Trust , is a consortium of organisations whose collective aim is to improve the understanding of veteran employment.Their study comes after a separate poll earlier this year found an alarming  per cent of civilians think veterans are more likely to suffer from more mental, physical and emotional issues than those who have never served.The YouGov report also found that  per cent of employers believe veterans are more likely to be “institutionalised”.And  per cent thought that serving in the Armed Forces “damages people”.Lee Holloway, Chief Executive of the Officers’ Association said: “There is a clear gulf between how the public perceive veterans and the reality.“Veterans are more likely to be employed for instance, regardless of disability or mental health.Air Vice-Marshal Ray Lock CBE and Chief Executive of the Forces in Mind Trust, said: “The transition out of military service into civilian le is most successful when all the elements, such as housing and employment, are tackled early, and holistically.“It’s important that these challenges are, though, represented in a balanced and proportionate way.Understanding the needs of the minority who do struggle should be set alongside the successful outcomes for the majority.“There is plenty of evidence to show that the public and employers hold inaccurate perceptions of the ex-Service community.“The efforts of the Veterans Work consortium should help redress the balance.”Tobias Ellwood, Minister for Defence People and Veterans, said: “Those who have served in our armed forces leave with a fantastic range of transferrable skills, including leadership, team work and resourcefulness.“Organisations can benefit signicantly from their experience, and so it’s important we dispel the myth that veterans are somehow damaged by their service.“We will continue to support our service leavers in whichever route they choose to take, through initiatives such as our Career Transition Partnership.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lion air jet not airworthy
story: About three minutes after the Boeing  took off for its journey to Pangkal Pinang, the plane made erratic altitude changes.Ten minutes later, the plane crashed into waters off the Java coast killing all  people on board.Last night Nurcahyo Utomo, head of Indonesias national transport safety committee said: This is the basis of our recommendation to Lion Air. In our view, the plane was not airworthy.Preliminary data transmitted by flight  now suggests the troubled plane dropped at incredible speed — falling from an altitude of m in just  seconds.A normal descent for an airliner would be about m to m per minute, aviation safety expert John Cox told Bloomberg.Data obtained by FlightRadar shows the Lion Air flight JT- descending at more than m per minute.“This thing really comes unglued,” said Mr Cox, who runs consulting company Safety Operating Systems.“The numbers are barely believable.”An analysis of data from the crashed plane by the Aviation Safety website described its speed and altitude during its  minutes of flying as “erratic”.The plane made a climbing left-hand turn after take-off, climbed to m and then dropped down to m.It then climbed again and continued unsteadily for a few minutes between m and m before the fatal plunge.The Boeing  Max involved in yesterday’s crash had flown a dferent route on Sunday.Similar data shows it had erratic movements immediately after takeoff, but managed to climb and maintain a steady altitude.Lion Air has confirmed the aircraft had a “technical problem” on the Sunday flight, “which had been resolved according to the procedure”.What caused the strange changes in altitude and speed, and why the pilot asked toto Jakarta moments after takeoff, will now be a major focus for investigators.According to aviation consultant and former pilot Alastair Rosenschein, we won’t have a definitive answer on what caused the crash until authorities recover the plane’s black box.“It is almost impossible to say just what happened,” Mr Rosenschein told CNN. “At this point, some sort of mechanical failure is probably the most likely, but this is purely speculative.”The aviation expert said that until the black box is found, it would remain unlikely authorities could figure out what brought down the plane.He noted it’s especially important to find the black box quickly because the doomed plane was a newer model.“What happened here could possibly affect the same model of aircraft flying in other parts of the world,” he said.Investigators have deployed underwater beacons to trace the flight’s black box recorders, but so far they are yet to make a discovery.The top priority will be finding the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder to help determine the cause, safety experts said.

title: wasp discovered amazon spider zombies
story: The nightmare bug turns spiders into helpless drones who abandon their own colonies to do the wasps bidding - before its larvae eats them alive.The gruesome discovery - made in Ecuador - was made by scientists from the University of British Columbia in Canada.They say the wasps behaviour is a particularly hardcore form of hijacking - which is when one animal manipulates another.After leaving their homes, the spiders are made to spin a special cocoon for the wasp larvae which will then hatch and eat the spider.Wasps manipulating the behaviour of spiders has been observed before, but not at a level as complex as this, said Philippe Fernandez-Fournier of the UBCs department of zoology.Not only is this wasp targeting a social species of spider but it’s making it leave its colony, which it rarely does.The parasitic wasp targets a spider called Anelosimus eximius known for living in large colonies and cooperating with others to capture prey and raise their young.Researchers noticed some of the spiders were infected with a parasitic larva and were seen wandering away from their colonies to spin enclosed webs.It was very odd because they don’t normally do that, so I started taking notes, said Fernandez-Fournier.It was then the stunned scientists noticed the larvae belonged to a unknown species of Zatypota wasp.These wasps are very elegant looking and graceful, said Samantha Straus, co-author of the study and PhD student in OBC’s department of zoology. But then they do the most brutal thing.A female wasp first lays an egg on a spider’s abdomen which then hatches and starts feeding off the spider.Then the spider deserts its colony and to create a cocoon for the larva - before waiting to be devoured the wasps young.This behaviour modication is so hardcore, Straus said.The wasp completely hijacks the spider’s behaviour and brain and makes it do something it would never do, like leave its nest and spinning a completely dferent structure.That’s very dangerous for these tiny spiders.Its not known how the wasps do this, but scientists believe it may be caused by an injection of hormones that make the spider think its in a dferent le-stage or cause it to disperse from the colonyWe think the wasps are targeting these social spiders because it provides a large, stable host colony and food source, Straus said.We also found that the larger the spider colony, the more likely it was that these wasps would target it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: skeleton mystery sea creature new zealand beach
story: The creatures strange features has left locals both terried and baffled and was originally assumed to be an alien.The bizarre beast appears to have two legs and a tail, sharp fangs and winged claws, in addition to a long point protruding from its head.Its decaying skeleton horried Christchurch residents Hanna Mary and her mother who spotted the critter while out on a beach walk in Rakaia Huts, Canterbury.Speaking to the NZ Herald, Hanna said: My first thought was that it was something alien, but I was more fascinated than anything.The pair were initially scared to touch the creature in case it was poisonous but then decided to take it to a taxidermist in the hope that they would clear up the mystery.But after inspection, the taxidermist was left just as bemused by the creatures origins as they were and Hanna revealed she turned to her family and friends for answers.I uploaded the photos on Facebook and we were all taking guesses, most people said skate.Dr. Francis revealed that the claws on the wings are called alar spines, which only male skates have to use for mating.Skates are a type of fish that have cartilage instead of bone as well as enlarged pectoral fins which are attached to their heads to form their disc-shaped body.Skates are harmless to humans and unlike stingrays, skates do not have a venomous spine in their tail. But, similar to Rays, their wings are often eaten.

title: first pic of the tiny hotpoint fridge freezer cable that sparked devastating grenfell tower blaze
story: Dr John Duncan Glover showed the inquiry a picture of the tiny wire connector thought to have overheated and started the deadly inferno, which caused the deaths of  people.Investigators recovered the evidence from a small relay compressor compartment at the bottom rear of the fridge freezer in the kitchen of Flat .The inquiry was told they also found three inches of damaged wire in one of the bedrooms of the same flat.Dr Glover, principal engineer at Failure Electricial, highlighted the poor crimp connection, which did not keep the wires tightly gripped as it was supposed to.He said spaces seen in images taken from CT scans suggested it had not been properly crimped.I found voids in all  cross-sections indicating the crimp was not nice and tight, he said.In a report prepared for the inquiry Dr Glover concluded: A probable cause of the fire is a poor crimp connection for... an overheated wire connector within the compressor relay compartment for the fridge freezerfrom Flat .He said: The overheating connector in my opinion was the first event that started burning the insulation on the wires that led to a short circuit.Dr Glover added: The overheating of the crimp starts the fire. It overheats, it glows, it ignites.A week after the deadly fire, the politan Police said it believed it had started in a fridge-freezer.Whirlpool, which makes Hotpoint machines, said its investigation found the model of fridge freezer showed no evidence of any fault and complied with all safety requirements.“We would like to reassure owners of these products that they are safe and they can continue to use them as normal,” the company said in a statement.“All fridges, freezers, and fridge freezers across all our UK brands are manufactured with solid metal or aluminium laminate flame-retardant back .”Dr Glover said refrigerators manufactured in the US must have a metal back casing, but in the UK and Europe it can be plastic.He explained: “That metallic backing would help to contain an internal fire, keep it inside the refrigerator, for a long time.“Instead of the plastic casing on the rear, which is combustible, contributing to the fire, you have a steel casing which is not.”Some  people, including a stillborn baby, died in the devastating June  fire, and another resident died the following January in what was the countrys deadliest domestic fire since World War Two.The public inquiry continues.

title: michael schumacher secret dream private life manager

Michael is world champion after  years.I remember saying to Michael, ‘On a professional level, things will be dferent for us.Last November,  Schumachers daughter has posted an inspirational message to his fans to keep the hope of his recovery aliveGina-Maria, , wrote on Instagram: There is only one happiness in this le, to love and be loved #keepfighting.One fan replied: Magnicent, the power of love, god bless your family #Keepfighting #TeamMichael.His we Corrina, , Gina-Maria and her brother Mick, , have rarely spoken out about his condition.However, the stars former manager Willi Weber said last October: I find it very unfortunate that Michaels fans do not know about his health. Why are they not being told the truth In  his team were forced to deny claims in a German magazine that he was now able to walk with the aid of therapists.

title: primary school scraps homework pupils stress
story: Children attending Littletown Primary Academy in Honiton, Devon, are being encouraged to read for  minutes at home instead.Teachers are testing the change with all pupils except Year Six between now and the end of the academic year.Headteacher David Perkins said the decision was based on research.A letter sent home to parents claimed that weekly written maths and English homework have little impact, according to analysis.And it can cause stress to families and is not always valued by staff, the note said.Mr Perkins added that spending  minutes reading at home every evening has a greater impact on pupil outcomes and le chances.Literacy subject leader Cathy Binmore said: “Reading is the foundation that underpins all other learning.Promoting a love of this will set our children up for a le of adventure and intrigue and will enable them to continue learning throughout their lives.”Children will also be encouraged to practice their times tables at home — which the school claimed is most beneficial way of improving maths skills.The change is aimed at reducing teachers’ workloads as well as taking the pressure off children and their families.And the school is raising money to buy more books to encourage reading at home instead.Mr Perkins said: “Reading for  minutes a day can make a massive dference to a child’s education but onlywe can give the children the best possible books to inspire their love of reading.“We want to reinvigorate our library with fresh and exciting books to read.”

title: post brexit immigration plans delays eu workers
story: Home Secretary Sajid Javid was forced to admit details of a post-Brexit visa scheme may not come out until after MPs are asked to vote on the PM’s Brexit deal on December .He said he could only “hope” an Immigration White Paper would be ready - but that a draft was being held up by other Government departments.The Sun can reveal the delay stems from a bitter Cabinet war over the PM’s bid to halt as much low-skilled immigration as possible.One Cabinet Minister said the PM was in a “minority of one” as colleagues demand concessions so businesses can continue to recruit low-skilled EU workers.Sources claim both Chancellor Philip Hammond and Business Secretary Greg Clark are blocking a bid to rush out the paper because they want to soften the proposals.The PM’s close aides want the completely isolated on this.The Ministers from the big economic departments won’t stand for it as they know how much the nation depends on lower skilled migrants.“Limiting immigration too much will do more potential damage to the economy than No Deal.”A Government-backed committee in September called for a ban on any foreign worker who would be earning less than £, a year from obtaining a visa for Brexit Britain.Speaking to the Home Affairs Select Committee yesterday, Mr Javid said that was “too rigid”.He refused to be directly drawn on talk of a Cabinet split.But he also repeatedly refused to back the PM’s target to bring net migration down below , – a target that hasn’t been met in seven years.He also insisted that the plan had to be “pro-business” as well as delivering on the results of the  Referendum.Brussels’ free movement rules were blamed by Leave campaigners for fuelling the explosion in EU migration over the past decade.Mr Javid insisted Brexit meant that Britain had a golden chance to design its own immigration system.And he admitted he had originally hoped to publish the Government’s plans in July.But he said: “I think when I first came into the department I was hoping I know, certainly, that it will be published by the end of the year.”One senior Eurosceptic Tory stormed: “The lack of preparedness and incoherence is shown by the fact that at the th hour they are having to admit to the utter disarray they are in on immigration.“They are not going to be taking back control of our borders.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may commons 200 vote defeat brexit deal
story: With just  days to go until the crucial “meaningful vote”, Cabinet ministers are considering urging her to abandon it.One has even said there is “zero chance” the deal will get through. But No  has warned that the PM will not ditch the deal — and will keep pushing it through Parliament until it passes.One Cabinet minister branded No’s refusal to change course in the face of overwhelming odds as “extraordinary”, adding: “There is zero chance the deal will pass now”.And a former minister – who is remaining loyal to Mrs May - has calculated that the Government will lose by a devastating  votes.The senior Tory warned of “a bandwagon effect” that is pushing an ever larger coalition of Brexiteer and Remainer MPs to side against Mrs May for a myriad dferent reasons, dubbing it “madness”.Another Cabinet minister told The Sun: “Theresa is still being told she can win this by the people around her in No.“It’s terrible advice and she deserves better, because they are going to bring her down.”By Tuesday night, a total of  Tory MPs had publicly declared their opposition to the deal - struck in Brussels on Sunday after  months of torturous negotiation - with more known to also oppose it.Mrs May was dealt a fresh hammer blow when loyal former Cabinet minister Sir Michael Fallon branded it “doomed”.Given that her deal is most likely dead, our politicians must start properly planning for a clean break from the EU to ensure minimal disruption.Evidently, the bloc is unwilling to compromise.Spain have already threatened us over Gibraltar and the French with fishing.The Government should prepare to call a national emergency to ensure we are ready in four months,necessary, to leave on our own terms.It is not good enough for the PM to plough on with her bad deal, blindly believing that she will get it through Parliament. The odds are stacked against her.The Government must pull its finger out and prepare for a No Deal scenario.The ex-Defence Secretary - forced to resign a year ago for sexual inappropriateness - stunned No by dubbing the agreement “the worst of all worlds”.Sir Michael also became the first senior Tory to call for a delay to Brexit on March  next year so negotiations for a better deal can be extended.Ministers have begun privately working on options for a Plan B within their own factions, but there is no agreement among them on what it should be yet.Tory whips are instead warning backbench MPs that the PM will refuse to abandon her deal evenMPs do vote it down on December .No will instead plan to put it to Parliament a second and even a THIRD time until it passes.One MP said: “They’re trying to bring it back at least twice - possibly a third time – after renegotiations.“I think she needs to be gone after the first time it falls, but they’re trying to keep her in position.”On another tense day in British politics:Mrs May began her frantic nationwide tour of the UK on Tuesday with visits to Wales and Northern Ireland to try to sell her Brexit deal to the country ahead of the showdown vote.She will also go to Scotland on Wednesday to insist the agreement delivers for fishermen by taking back control of the UK’s waters.But ahead of the PM’s arrival in Belfast, DUP chief Ms Foster said her visit would be “a waste of time” as she won’t reopen the agreement for an Irish backstop that sees dferent regulations for Ulster and the rest of the UK.Hitting back, Mrs May insisted the deal “protects” the UK, adding: “A very clear message that we have got here in Northern Ireland but where as well is that people do not want toto uncertainty and ision”.Cabinet ministers remained loyal in public today.Health Secretary Matt Hancock insisted MPs “should vote for the deal” saying it wasn’t “just the Government’s position - it’s the right thing to do”.Askedhe could guarantee that no-one would diethere was a no-deal Brexit, Mr Hancock told the Commons Health Committee: “As my permanent secretary tells me, we shouldn’t use words like guarantee.“What we can say is that we are confident thateverybody does what they need to do then there will be the continuity of supply.”Brexiteers last night warned that the Treasury’s analysis of the deal should be discarded as “yet more Project Fear”.The Sun can reveal that four dferent scenarios will be modelled against a baseline of staying in the EU, and all four are expected to show growth will be lost because of the decision to leave.They are the PM’s Chequers plan to align regulations on goods with the EU, membership of the EEA, a looser Canada-style free trade deal and no deal at all.Leading Tory Brexiteer Steve Baker said: “The reputation of government economics is in the gutter. That must change.“It’s time for the Chancellor to publish all his assumptions and full model documentation so we can begin the process of recovery.”Meanwhile Home Secretary Sajid Javid on Tuesday night admitted there was “no guarantee” the UK would be given access to two critical EU-wide crime databases.He admitted the Political Declaration only laid out plans to cooperate on finding “approximate measures” to cooperate on crime fighting.Currently police chiefs can access the Schengen Information Systemand ECRIS, the European Criminal Records Information System to check suspects against a list of third country nationals.Police accesses SISII more than  million times last year.Mr Javid told MPs: “Within this document [the Political Declaration] it’s within scope but it’s not guaranteed.”The Home Secretary insisted “almost of all my counterparts” in the EU want to cooperate on security in “much the same way”.But Labour’s Stephen Doughty revealed the PM’s chief of staff admitted  to opposition MPs at a private briefing on Monday night it would be “very dficult” to maintain access to SISII.Mr Doughty said: “Gavin Barwell told us it’s going to be an even bigger challenge to stay connected to SISII than it was to join it in the first place.”Ministers are also on course for a fresh showdown with the House of Commons when it emerged Downing Street will not publish the full Brexit legal advice – giving MPs “full, reasoned position statement” instead.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may government accused veil secrecy ndas no deal brexit
story: New figures revealed the Department for Transport alone has  non-disclosure agreements in force - forbidding companies and organisations from discussing plans about borders and customs.The Department for Exiting the European Unionhas six – and insists they are “entirely normal practice”.Just two months ago Theresa May branded the use of NDAs by employers to gag staff as “unethical”.But haulage firms and drug companies are thought to be among those who now face an injunctionthey break the terms of the ious gagging orders.Lib Dem MP and Best for Britain campaigner Layla Moran stormed: “The Government is throwing a veil of secrecy over critical plans.“There is a massive element of hypocrisy that the Prime Minister would say she opposes non-disclosure agreements but yet her departments use them. It is shameless.”The revelations in a string of written Parliamentary answers came as a scathing cross-party report warned of chaos at ports and motorways in a No Deal.MPs on the Public Accounts Committee slammed inadequate planning and “complacency” at the Department of Transport.They said there was a “real risk” of chaos at Dover and found “slow progress and poor communication” around work to avoid disruption through schemes such as Project Brock, where overflow traffic parked on the M in Kent.Separately, representatives of the food and drinks industry warned it was already too late for companies to book extra space to stockpile extra supplies in the run-up to Brexit in March because of over-demand.Ian Wright, boss of the Food and Drink Federation, said warehouses for frozen and chilled food were “for all practical purposes booked out at the moment”.A Government spokesperson said it was wrong to suggest NDAs were “designed to prevent organisations from raising any concerns”.He said: “They are in place simply to protect commercial and sensitive issues, which is consistent across government.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit deal worst both worlds
story: He talks in sweeping generalisations and is often criticised for inaccuracies, even outright hoods.How then should we react to the leader of the free world claiming the UK’s withdrawal agreement with the EU could mean that we would be “unable to trade” with the US This is a classic example of the need to take Donald Trump seriously, but not literally.There are no imaginable circumstances in which Britain will be blocked from trading with America.We can do so at present, even as full members of the EU.If we couldn’t, I must have imagined visiting the States and buying their products.Trade happens and will continue to do so, whatever arrangements the UK finally finds itself in.But President Trump’s intervention speaks to a deeper, more subtle truth.If the UK effectively remains in an EU customs union and without control over our regulatory system then it’s dficult to see how trade with the US will accelerate and flourish.The same goes with the rest of the non-EU world.The dficulty with Theresa May’s Withdrawal Agreement is that it substantially limits the capacity for the UK to strike its own trade deals.Indeed, it would make such deals almost impossible.Downing Street has hit back at this by pointing to wording in the agreement that states the UK will be entitled to reach arrangements with other countries.But this amounts to little more than a theoretical possibility given it is not made clear when,ever, we will finally be out of this “customs territory”.To grasp this problem, it is important to understand how trade negotiations work.Let’s say you and I sit round a table and go through all the things hindering trade between our two nations.Perhaps I am applying high tarfs on your wine and you are applying exorbitant tarfs on my cars.We negotiate, so more of my countrymen can drink your wine, and more of your citizens can drive my cars.To reach such accords, you need to be in full control of your own customs arrangements.If my starting point is that I can’t reduce the tarf on your wine because I’m locked into an agreement with the EU that fixes the tarf, my negotiations with you are unlikely to get off the ground.American wine, for instance, is subject to a tarf of either .p or p per ­bottle, depending on strength.A bottle of Jack Daniel’s is hit by a  per cent import tarf to the EU, while American cars are subject to a ten per cent import tarf.Meanwhile, the EU recently announced a plan to hit American motorcycles, such as Harley-Davidsons with a  per cent tarf — hugely pushing up the price.A larger part of the negotiation tends to focus on regulatory barriers to trade.Although tarfs on products mean higher prices in the shops, they do not necessarily prevent foreign prod­­ucts getting to the market.But dferences in regulation can have just this effect.If, to oversimply, all of your nails need, by law, to be in long and all of the nails in my country need to be in long, we won’t see much trade in nails between us — evenno tarfs are imposed.To improve our trading relations we need to look at whether we can agree to align some of our regulations, repeal some or respect each other’s regulatory standards.If we do not control our rules and cannot alter or abolish them, negotiations are pretty pointless.And not just with the US, but with other major economies, such as Australia and Japan.The UK faces a classic trade- off here.If what you prioritise above all  is to minimise any friction in trade between the UK and the EU, you will want to stay highly aligned with the EU’s regulations — and you may well conclude that it is easier to simply stay in the EU itself.In that case, you will also probably want the UK to join the euro, because having a dferent currency to France and Germany adds costs to our trade with them.Butyou are looking to the rest of the world, you may feel we should be able to strike a simple but comprehensive free trade deal with the EU.Trade across the Channel might not be as seamless as at present, but we would be free to strike deals to improve trade across the Atlantic and the Pacic.If Mrs May’s is the deal we are left with, those hoping for a global Britain post-Brexit will be deeply disappointed.Even a no-deal scenario would at least unshackle the UK from EU rules and provide more autonomy over our future trading relationships with the rest of the world.Trade with the EU is important to the UK, but it is declining.Over the next decade,  per cent of all global economic growth is predicted to come from outside the European Union.If you see Brexit as a historic opportunity to make Britain a global trading nation, you will have a lot of sympathy with President Trump’s sentiments.This might explain why so many see Mrs May’s proposals as the worst of both worlds.They surrender our seat at the EU table, without giving us the freedom to properly reach out across the seas.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
