title: leaked report no deal brexit theresa may
story: Dominic Raab said it was a rehash of Project fear as fresh analysis set to be released today will show leaving with no agreement will hit the economy by . per cent over the next  years.Meanwhile, the PMs hated Brexit agreement will only leave GDP down . per cent over the same period, it suggests.The leaks from the Dailycome as ministers prepare to release a series of analyses on dferent Brexit scenarios later today.Its thought that the economic warnings are part of Nos plans to try and get MPs to vote for Mrs Mays deal.But ex-Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith warned: At the end of the day, almost all financial forecasts are wrong.Today The Sun revealed that Mrs May could lose the vote by up to  votes.This morning a gloomy Philip Hammond claimed that Brexit would make Britain poorer - and that staying in the EU would give us the best economic advantage.He warned that Mrs Mays deal was better than a No Deal Brexit and the PMs deal would deliver a Leave outcome with close to the economic benefits of Remain.Speaking to the BBC he said: Im not trying to scare anybody, I reject the term scare mongering.We know there would be signicant delays at channel ports, checks would have to be introduced.The dreary Chancellor said it was the only way to deliver Brexit while protecting our economy.Butthe deal doesnt get through Parliament, he refused to rule anything out, opposed the deal, in a boost for the PM,  per cent said the EU wouldnt make further concessions to us, and only a quarter said booting her out would help the deal.But when asked whether the deal is all such material went public - and hinted that only some of it will go out.Furious MPs are set to raise the issue in the Commons later.She will add: So we will be out of the Common Agricultural title: brits rush eu passports brexit day
story: Applications for EU passports are soaring as Brits try to get alternative ones ahead of  Britain leaving the EU on March  .Some countries had a spike immediately after the referendum in , but since then applications have continued to rise.Ireland, Sweden and Spain have all reported huge hikes in the Brits seeking to get their hands on one.Sweden has a record , applications last year, and , this year so far.Ireland have had , a MONTH from Brits up to the end of December.Thats around , more a month than last year.Theres also been a sharp rise in Northern Irish citizens applying for Irish passports too - with , applications this year.Niall Collins, the Fianna Fáil TD, said: “You will see an increase in applications after Brexit day.A lot of people still don’t think it will ultimately happen . . . and they are maybe just holding back pending that.”Brits have already been advised to renew their passports before Brexit to make sure they have at least  months left after March.million are thought to need to renew theirs in the case of being unable to travel in the case of a No Deal Brexit.Ministers said: If you are planning travel after  March , and your passport will be affected by the new validity rules, we recommend you consider renewing your passport soon to avoid any delay, as the passport issuing service can get busy, especially in the spring.Italy: Italian citizenship is passed down from parent to child - so as long as you have Italian blood you could be elligible to get a passport.Germany: If your family were stripped of German passports during the Nazi era you may have a right to re-claim German citizenship. But there are strict rules about dual nationality. This was popular for Brits last year, with a huge jump in applications.France: Anyone who has lived in France continunually for five years ofr more to apply.Malta and Cyprus: If you have a grandparent from there you could be elligible. title: paloma faith new mum is difficult
story: “Motherhood was much more dficult than I anticipated because I hadn’t heard the truth and I think not enough people speak about it,” Paloma said. “Obviously everyone’s experience is dferent and I have met mums who sailed through it but I didn’t. I was really shell-shocked.”It seems like such a simple admission. But the reality is that with most celebrities, from the Kardashians to the Beckhams, projecting an unfeasibly perfect image of parenthood as part of their brand, many expectant mums think a new baby is going to be a walk in the park.The reality for most of us really couldn’t be further from the truth.Paloma also talked about the dficulty of balancing being a new mother with having a career.“I found it very dficult, the pull between wanting to be the greatest mother ever but also trying to sustain an inherently selfish career,” she said.The transition from being a woman with a career and all the time in the world to a mother wanting to continue working is no easy feat.There’s a period of adjustment and, often, the road is rocky. So here’s the reality, for what it’s worth.In my experience, EVERY woman who is a parent finds motherhood hard at some point or ­another, but especially at the beginning. And the women who seem to be sailing through it are often putting on a brave face, partly because they feel under pressure to do so.Often, people’s public portrayal of their le, including motherhood, is heavily edited, airbrushed and ­censored.The pressure on women for everything, including motherhood, to be “perfect” is clear.And,that isn’t your experience, with everyone  seemingly acing it, the pressure is on to pretend that it is.The vicious cycle is born. So it’s brave of Paloma to talk about her experience out loud.Given that every mum in the history of the universe has felt this way about motherhood at one time or another, we should be more honest about admitting it to be true.Modern pressures are making it so dficult I have to say I’m so glad I’m not raising a child today.The internet had still not been invented. The Twitter and Instagram inventors had probably not even been born.When I was growing up the only “influencers” in my le were my mum and dad.We ate as a family every night and there were three channels on the TV that all stopped airing by midnight. You had to make your own entertainment.Nowadays you can’t move for influencers on YouTube, Instagram and Twitter telling your kids how they should look or feel — and ­promoting lestyles that are simply unattainable.No wonder there has been such a dramatic rise in young people self-harming and taking anti- depressants. Too many influencers, who are hashtag “blessed”, don’t talk about the dficult stuff.Paloma, by the way, is raising her child as “gender neutral” — a ­decision that seems to be another indication of the pressures that ­people are under to do the right thing by their children.Too much choice and too much pressure to do the right thing and be the perfect parent can lead to paranoia.The best advice I could give a parent now that my own two are  and  is to find your own path.Don’t look too hard at what everyone  is doing.Don’t compare yourself to any other mothers, especially not celebrities with a team of personal trainers and chefs, and who snap back into shape two weeks after giving birth.Instead of aiming for perfect, just try to do your best.Listen, understand and give your child the one thing that really does matter: Self-esteem.Talk to other women, and be honest, evenyou are finding it hard. Because it IS bloody hard.So good for Paloma for being honest and fighting the tide of propaganda about motherhood.Because being honest makes it easier for other women who might be struggling.ISN’T it incredible to think that a hundred years ago, on November , , women were allowed to stand for parliament in the UK for the very first time Fast forward to the  General Election when  female MPs were elected.Yes, that’s in relation to  male MPs, so we still have a way to go – but look how far we have come.I know I am biased, but women are such a brilliant parliamentary asset.Look at all the things they bring to the table and to the conversation.Women are great listeners, good mediators, brilliant diplomats and inspiring promoters of family and equal rights. Oh, and we are resilient.Just look at Theresa May who, at a time when most men would be hiding under the duvet and emitting a high-pitched wailing noise, is rising to the unbelievable challenges being thrown at her by the Brexit process – and enjoying beans on toast with her husband Philip in the evening.Compare her to a politician such as Jacob Rees-Mogg who is doing everything he possibly can to promote himself and his political ambitions – rather than focusing on what the country needs.The PM is the living embodiment of resilience – a tough old bird indeed.ANYONE in a long-term marriage should take note of Dolly Parton’s insights on what makes her -year union work.“When people ask me what’s the key to my long marriage and lasting love, I always say, ‘Stay gone’,” the singer, reveals. “I travel a lot, but we really enjoy each other when we’re together and the little things we do.”Her husband Carl doesn’t like to appear in public or walk the red carpet – so she leaves him at home.Instead of glamorous date nights, they take trips in a “little camper”, go on picnics and eat at local restaurants, including a drive-thru McDonald’s.But eventhey are having a quiet night in, she says she always makes sure she is “fixed up for him because I don’t believe in going home and being a slouch”.You’ve got to love Dolly.NOT many people can ooze class, charm and elegance with their leg raised higher than their head – at the age of .Butthere’s one woman who can, it’s the glorious Darcey Bussell, who must be one of the nicest, and classiest, women in showbiz today.Goldman was one of the first corporate firms to introduce “lactation rooms” for women to express milk and it also runs free prenatal fitness classes at its office gym.It also has on-site day care where employees’ children are cared for  days per year for free.All of which is great – and let’s hope more companies follow suit for new parents.Mind you, it’s not like the need for childcare ever really stops – I still need an emergency nanny occasionally when my -year-old daughter loses her keys or my -year-old son locks himself out.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mo farah golliwog christmas market
story: The sportsman was depicted as a racist caricature striking his classic Mo-bot pose in a white vest with his surname on it at a stall in Rochester.The term golly doll stems from a fictional character depicted as a rag doll in the children’s story The Adventures Of Two Dutch Dolls And A Golliwogg created by writer Florence Kate Upton in the th Century.The name became associated with racist connotations when it was used as a derogatory term for black people in World War Two.A photo also shows a Bob Marley doll on sale for £. at Rochester Christmas Market.Following complaints over the golly dolls at the council-run event, officials blasted the caricature of the national hero, adding selling the dolls was completely inappropriate.Councillor and leader of Medway Labour Group Vince Maple said: Mo Farah is a national hero and an internationally respected athlete so to have somebody selling dolls of this nature is completely inappropriate at a council-run Christmas event.Its supposed to a Dickensian event and these dolls are neither Christmassy nor Dickensian.Cllr Maple previously tweeted that he had received an email about a stall selling the racist dolls.He said he had written urgently to Medway Council officers to seek action on the matter.Cllr Howard Doe, cabinet member for community services, said: We do not allow Gollys to be sold at the Rochester Christmas Market.We permitted the sale of Rasta dolls within the City of Rochester Craft Fair, at the Rochester Christmas Market last year.However, following reports that similar dolls were being sold at the market last weekend we have reviewed the situation again.Although the dolls are not labelled as Gollys we understand that they may unintentionally cause offence to some visitors.We have therefore decided to ask the stallholder to withdraw the dolls from sale.The banning of the dolls at the market comes just months after a man was fined £ for displaying a golliwog with noose around its neck in his flat window in North Wales.Jason Wakefield-Jones, , was reported to police after two residents spotted the doll peering out of the first-floor of his flat with a noose around its neck.The property in Prestatyn, North Wales, was across the road from two Indian restaurants and Wakefield-Jones admitted displaying it with intent to cause harassment, alarm or distress and that the offence was racially aggravated.District Judge Gwyn Jones at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court in North Wales told Jason Wakefield-Jones: “You may think that was funny but it was not.”

title: family hoard food no deal brexit
story: Nevine Mann, , and her husband Richard, , said they have been buying extra food and medicine each time they go shopping ahead of the March  Brexit deadline.The couple, who live in Illogan, near Redruth, with their three children Oliver, , Ethan,  and Paige, five, have also stockpiled tinned goods, dried milk, coffee and pasta.Nevine insists stockpiling is a matter of survivalTheresa Mays Brexit deal doesnt make it past the parliament vote on December .Since Brexit negotiations began, Nevine said they started buying more dried food and believe they have enough goods to survive a No Deal Brexit for at least four months.She said: The results of a No Deal Brexit would be catastrophic in terms of getting supplies in the country, certainly in the short term. Were waiting to seethe new deal goes through or not.She continued: If that doesnt go through, it will be No Deal because there wont be enough time to sort another one out.We started buying extra of things we would usually buy. When we are shopping we buy beans for now and beans for later, rice for now and rice for later. There are a few things we wouldnt usually buy, like sources of vegetarian protein and powdered milk.Nevine, who home schools the couples children, added: Weve got baked beans, chickpeas, couscous, pasta - weve got things like tea, coffee, Ovaltine... We also bought Marmite so we can have some flavour.While the stockpiling measures may seem extreme to some, Nevine insists the family are not going over the top, adding: Weve got enough to get us through the first couple of monthsthere is No Deal.The Mann familys cupboards are already stocked with  tins of beans,  cans of tuna, large tubs of mayonnaise, eight cans of chopped tomatoes and four packets of passata.Nevine added: Its not about being able to live comfortably, its about being able to survive.The familys stockpiling comes after industry leaders revealed food warehouses are now fully stocked for the next six months after an unprecedented rush in the days following the publication of Theresa May’s draft Brexit deal.The Food Storage and Distribution Federation warned that Britain isn’t set up for stockpiling food but storage space is now fully reserved from January to April - usually the quietest time of the year.FSDF boss Shane Brennan told the : “It’s a problem, because food is manufactured or stored on a just-in-time basis, and the system isn’t built for stockpiling.“But because of Brexit, every business that wants to guarantee its supply into UK shelves is looking for additional warehouse space right now.”On December , MPs will vote on the withdrawal agreement that was approved by EU leaders on November , .Parliament has demanded that the Brexit treaty can only be ratied by the Government after it has been “approved by a resolution of the House of Commons on a motion moved by a minister of the crown”.The vote will be a straight yes no format in a bid to make a decisive and unequivocal decision on the PMs deal.But the outlook for the vote isnt positive as Theresa May has already had two ministers resign over the deal and her own Brexit Secretary, Dominic Raab, also quit as the draft deal was presented to Parliament.Labour and factions within her own party have declared their intention to vote against it.

story: NewsBrexit WILL be worse for UK economy than staying in EU, confirms Philip HammondThe Chancellor has just destroyed every scrap of Theresa Mays Brexit idend - and todays official economic analysis is bound to prompt fresh calls to cancel BrexitShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video philip-hammond-confirms-brexit-make-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit WILL make the nation worse off - no matter how good Theresa Mays deal is, the Chancellor has announced. Philip Hammond sounded the warning as damning legal advice on the Prime Ministers deal is published later today. The comments - almost unheard of from a Tory Cabinet minister - are bound to prompt fresh calls to cancel Brexit. They come as a poll shows % would choose to Remain in a second EU referendum - compared to % who would pick Theresa Mays deal, and % backing No Deal. The Prime Minister has launched a two-week campaign to save her deal ahead of a vote by MPs on December . She is trying to convince a coalition of Brexiteer and Remainer rebels, including almost  Tories, to change their minds and back her.   To convince MPs, Theresa May has repeatedly boasted there will be a Brexit idend to spend on the NHS. But the Chancellor told BBC Breakfast: If the only consideration, the only consideration, was the economy, then the analysis shows clearly remaining in the European Union would be a better outcome for the economy, but not by much. He could only say the Prime Ministers deal will put the UK very close to the economic benefits of remaining in - rather than being better than Remaining. And he admitted: Remaining in the single market would give us an economic advantage, yes. Parts of the governments Brexit economic analysis has been leaked to the Dailyahead of its publication today. According to the reports, Treasury forecasts show that Britain will be poundbn worse off under a no-deal Brexit.   Its expected to show that under the Chequers agreement, which forms the basis of Mays deal, the UKs GDP will be between  and % lower over  years thanit had stayed in the EU. Chancellor Philip Hammond insisted there would only be a modest impact from a Brexit with a deal. But in No Deal he admitted food prices could soar. If theres no deal it is quite likely there would be a negative impact on food prices, he told Sky News. The Brexit deal agreed by Theresa May and the EU covers two areas: the Withdrawal Agreement, covering the UKs exit from the EU, and the Political Declaration on a Future Framework, which sets out the relationship with the EU after Britain leaves. Key details on the Brexit deal include: . The Withdrawal AgreementThe transition period can be extended until  - after the next election Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK A backstop could extend EU customs rules UK-wide - and wed need Brussels permission to quit European courts will still have a big hold on the UK. The Future FrameworkComprehensive arrangements that will create a free trade area - not exactly the frictionless trade hoped for Possible EU access to British fishing waters We would remain tied to European courts Wed respect human rights laws Visas needed for long term trips to the EU It has built in vagueness - kicking the can down the road for further negotiationsRead about the deal in more depth here.  We import a lot of food including a lot of food from the EU. In a no deal scenario we could expect the cost of that to increase. Ian Murray, Labour MP and backer of anti-Brexit campaign Best For Britain, said: Behind these figures are peoples livelihoods, with workers losing their jobs and businesses scaling back. Rather than producing figures to try and show that her deal is not as bad as no deal, the government should be focused on the best way to grow our economy - by giving voters the opportunity to remain in the EU.

title: family prepare no deal brexit
story: NewsFamily prepare for No Deal Brexit by stockpiling essential itemsNevine Mann, , and her husband Richard, , from Cornwall have enough goods to survive a no-deal Brexit for at least four monthsShareCommentsByJohn Bett:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsNevine Man with her daughter Paige aged five, at their home in Cornwall "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family are getting ready for Brexit by stocking up on essential items - such as tea bags, baked beans and Marmite. Married couple Nevine Mann, , and Richard, , have been buying extra food and medicine every time they go shopping so they are prepared for when Britain leaves the European Union. So far they have stockpiled chickpeas, kidney beans, tuna, pasta, rice, couscous, chopped tomatoes, sterilised milk, tinned corn, beans, paracetamol and ibuprofen. The family have also bought piles of aspirin, Calpol, dried milk, honey, Marmite, porridge oats, raisins, bread, flour, yeast and coffee. In addition, the clan also boats supplies of tea, sugar, apple juice, orange juice, Ovaltine and hand soap.  They believe they have now amassed enough goods on their kitchen table to survive a no-deal Brexit - for at least four months. Their cupboards are already stocked with  tins of beans,  cans of tuna, large tubs of mayonnaise, eight cans of chopped tomatoes and four packets of passata. There are also two large tubs of milk powder, several large bags of rice, pasta, tri colour quinoa and couscous. Since the Brexit negotiations began, Nevine said they started buying more dried food and fruit as it would last longer, as well as extra pet food.  The expanded shopping list also includes seeds so she can grow her own food in her garden, and equipment to pury rainwater. The Manns also have solar  on the roof and a -gallon water tank as they fear power could also be in short supply once Britain exits the EU. Nevine said she was also stockpiling her own medication, as she takes anti-epilepsy and blood-thinning drugs. And the couple, who live in Illogan, Cornwall, with her three children Oliver, , Ethan,  and Paige, five, insisted it wasnt about luxuries - but was a matter of survival.  Nevine, a former midwe, said: A little while ago we were aware that Brexit was in the offing, and it seemed like there would be issues with securing a deal. The results of a no deal Brexit would be catastrophic in terms of getting supplies in the country, certainly in the short term. We started buying extra of things we would usually buy. When we are shopping we buy beans for now and beans for later, rice for now and rice for later. Weve got about enough for four months.  The Manns have been doing their shopping at their local Sainsburys, Tesco and Aldi stores. Nevine, who homeschools the couples children, added: There are a few things we wouldnt usually buy, like sources of vegetarian protein and powdered milk. Weve got baked beans, chickpeas, couscous, pasta - weve got things like tea, coffee, Ovaltine, things like that. We also bought marmite so we can have some flavour.. Were basically there now so we will slow down now. Were not going over the top, weve got enough to get us through the first couple of monthsthere is no deal.  Were planting seeds in the garden and weve got extra to plant in spring. No deal Brexit is looking more and more likely, were waiting to seethe new deal goes through or not. If that doesnt go through it will be no deal because there wont be enough time to sort another one out. Its not about being able to live comfortably, its about being able to survive.

title: living wage boost thousands workers
story: NewsLiving Wage boost for thousands of workers in Heathrow Airport supply chainEXCLUSIVE: The west London travel hub announced the pay hike for an estimated , workersShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  NOV NewsHeathrow Airport announced the pay boost for workers in its supply chain "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritains biggest airport is banning zero-hours’ contracts and insisting suppliers pay workers the “real”LivingWage, we can reveal. In a major victory for campaigners, Heathrow Airport ruled all contractors must sign up to paying their staff at least the voluntary rate which is higher than the Government’s legal minimum. The move is set to benefit an estimated , of low-paid workers who are vital for the hub to operate. Transport bosses also told would-be contractors staff cannot be placed on zero-hours’ deals and must instead be guaranteed a flow of work. The shake-up, which executives have dubbed a “roadmap”, will apply to all new contracts signed from December. Staff with suppliers who have existing deals with Heathrow – which already pays its , directly-employed workers at least theLivingWage- must wait until the end of  before all benefit. LivingWageFoundation director Tess Lanning said: “Heathrow’s commitment to pay a realLivingWagehas already had a huge impact on workers.  “Low pay can be tackled in our offices, shops, warehouses and airports, but we now need to see more employers follow Heathrow’s lead and commit to a fair day’s pay for a hard day’s work.” Campaigners want businesses to commit to paying the realLivingWagerather than the Government’s NationalLivingWage, which is a re-branded minimum legal floor. The minimum pay rate for workers aged  and over is pound. compared with theLivingWage, paid by employers accredited with theLivingWageFoundation, which is pound. an hour in London and pound outside the capital. Analysts calculate the voluntary rate taking into account costs like housing, travel and healthy food, and extras like kids’ birthday presents.  Bosses say it helps companies’ reputations, employee retention and boosts staff motivation. Heathrow said a realLivingWagewould produce “higher morale, productivity and lower turnover” among workers. Some % of “target contracts” already in operation will be amended by autumn  to take effect of its new rules, with all workers at contractors earning at least theLivingWageby the end of .  One directly-employed worker who benefits from the realLivingWage, Alison Neill of the airport’s business support centre in Glasgow said: “Before I earned theLivingWage, I was struggling to keep on top of escalating debt, which was affecting my health, and quality of le. “One year on from being lted onto theLivingWageand I’m now on top of my finances, much happier and more motivated in my role because I’m no longer worried about being overwhelmed with debt.”   Trades Union Congress regional secretary Sam Gurney said: “We welcome the commitment of major employers like Heathrow Airport to ensure that their people and those in their supply chains receive LondonLivingWageand have regular guaranteed hours. “Heathrow’s roadmap must help ensure that those workers who do not currently receive LondonLivingWagewill do so as soon as possible.”

title: tories refuse publish brexit legal
story: NewsTories REFUSE to publish Brexit legal advice in flagrant defiance of ParliamentTheresa May was clearly ordered by MPs to publish "any legal advice in full" - now shes refusing to do itShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsTheresa May was clearly ordered by Parliament to publish any legal advice in full "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ministers are refusing to publish full legal advice on Brexit in a flagrant defiance of Parliament. MPs passed a motion two weeks ago that ordered ministers to provide any legal advice in full on Theresa Mays deal. At the time, Commons Speaker John Bercow confirmed the motion should take effect adding: It is not just an expression of opinion. But today Chancellor Philip Hammond said the government will only publish a summary of the legal advice. The Tory Cabinet minister said it will be a reasoned position statement, but added: What we are not going to do is publish the raw legal advice from the attorney general to the Cabinet.  He told Sky News: The clear constitutional precedent of this country is the advice of the attorney general to the government is private The government has to have access to private legal advice so it can make decisions that are properly made. But Labour, who brought forward the House of Commons motion, reacted with fury. Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said: Not good enough. Parliament won the right to see the full legal advice and that is precisely what we expect to see. Labour will not let ministers off the hook.  The government did not contest the motion, meaning it passed without a traditional Commons vote. However it still passed - and was only not contested because ministers feared they would suffer a far more embarrassing Tory revolt. Tory Brexiteer Sir Bill Cash today backed Labours call for full legal advice. This is a massively important constitutional question, he said. And he rejected the claim it would have a chilling effect on future advice given by the Attorney General. The Brexit deal agreed by Theresa May and the EU covers two areas: the Withdrawal Agreement, covering the UKs exit from the EU, and the Political Declaration on a Future Framework, which sets out the relationship with the EU after Britain leaves. The Withdrawal AgreementThe transition period can be extended until  - after the next election Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK A backstop could extend EU customs rules UK-wide - and wed need Brussels permission to quit European courts will still have a big hold on the UK. The Future FrameworkComprehensive arrangements that will create a free trade area - not exactly the frictionless trade hoped for Possible EU access to British fishing waters We would remain tied to European courts Wed respect human rights laws Visas needed for long term trips to the EU It has built in vagueness - kicking the can down the road for further negotiationsRead about the deal in more depth here. Under the ministerial code it quite clearly states that the Attorney Generals opinion must be sought on critical legal decision in good time, he said. And that being available to the Cabinet, I dont really see why it shouldnt be available to the people and to Parliament. Meanwhile Sajid Javid yesterday refused to confirm an immigration paper will be published before MPs vote on the Brexit deal on December . He was only able to say he hoped it would be released in time. Theresa May is widely expected to lose the House of Commons vote on her blindfold deal after more than  Tory or DUP MPs indicated they will vote against it.

title: british girl 2 found tunisian
story: NewsBritish girl, , found on Tunisian beach after wandering from hotels kids clubElla Bryson, who was on a Thomas Cook holiday with her parents, was said to be distressed and tearful when she was found by a fellow holidaymakerShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsParents Billy and Claire Bryson with daughter Ella "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA two-year-old British child was found wandering along a Tunisian beach after vanishing from a hotel kids club. Little Ella Bryson was distressed and tearful when she was found all alone by a fellow holidaymaker - and is still traumatised by the ordeal. Her furious parents Billy and Claire fear the worst could have happenedit wasnt for the kind stranger. And they claim the organisers of the kids club didnt even realise she was missing. Dad Billy, , from Angus, Scotland, said: Somebody could have grabbed her on the beach or she could have gone into the water and drowned. If somebody had picked her up, how were security going to know that she wasn’t just crying for her mum ” The family were on holiday at the Sahara Beach AquaPark Resort, near the city of Monastir, with their other kids, Ruby, nine, and Billie, four.  Ellas parents, who booked their holiday through Thomas Cook, had dropped her off in the kids club run by the hotel as opposed to the travel firm. About  minutes later, a fellow holidaymaker brought a distressed Ella back to Billy – having found her wandering alone on a nearby beach. Mum Claire, , said her daughter was in such a state when she was ed to her - commenting on how she was red and shaking. “It’s a parent’s worst nightmare,” said Claire.  “The nightmares I’ve been having since have been terrible. This is something none of us should have had to deal with.” Billy said he complained to a rep about what happened, only to be told the rep wasnt even aware of the incident. He said: When I went back to tell her that my daughter had been brought back to us, she wasn’t even aware that she was missing. She had no clue where my daughter was. “She was saying, ‘oh my God, I’m so sorry’. I said, ‘sorry  I could have never seen my daughter again – she’s two. You’re supposed to be the adult – how could you let my two-year-old daughter vanish ’ He added: “You always think about the worst that could happen.  More then a month ing home from holiday, Ellas parents said she is still traumatised by her experience. Dad Billy said Ella, now three, grips onto his hand as tight as she can while theyre out in public, and climbs on him to be carried. He said before, she was never like that.  He added: “Even now,we go to Asda, she’s holding your hand as tight as she can or she’s climbing to get up or she’s wanting to sit in the trolley.” The family met the guest who found Ella at a disco. Billy said: “We can’t thank her enough.” Meanwhile, in a post on social media directed at Thomas Cook, Claire strongly criticised the company – threatening the firm with legal action and vowing never to travel with it or go to the resort again.  She wrote: What did Ella have to do  Be kidnapped or drown or something for them to take it seriously ” A Thomas Cook spokeswoman said: “Customer safety is our first priority, so we were very concerned to hear of this incident and we understand how distressing it must have been. “We are urgently investigating with the hotel to get to the bottom of what happened and make any changes needed.” The Sahara Beach AquaPark was contacted for comment.

story: NewsDads horror after discovering thick layer of mould on baby milk from TescoOliver Turner of Lincolnshire gave a bottle to his eight-month old son Alfie before realising the expiration dateShareByLaura Forsyth:,  NOV NewsThe bottle of milk was almost three months out of date"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad panicked after feeding his baby out of date milk he says he bought from Tesco just the day before. Oliver Turner of Lincolnshire claims he bought three small bottles of Aptamil Pro Futura No formula from his local store on Monday. He and his we gave one bottle to their eight-and-a-half month old baby Alfie later that day. But when the next bottle was opened Mrs Turner was shocked to find a layer mould floating on top of the milk. The family then checked the bottles and saw they were almost three months out of date. Oliver told Lincolnshire Live: “We normally buy powder formula but recently moved to a dferent type as Alfie was bigger.   “The Tesco in Market Deeping didn’t sell the one we needed so my we bought three bottles of the formula just to tide us over. “When she opened the second bottle and she saw all of the mould she came and showed me. “That’s when we checked the date and it said went out of date at the end of August. “We were both worried really. Alfie was already asleep and we were both worried that he would be ill. “Luckily he has been OK. But last night I couldn’t stop tossing and turning, waiting for him to wake up and be unwell.   “Maybe the bottle was an exception, but it shouldn’t be a worry that you have. “The customer service team at Tesco have been pretty poor, they offered us a pound digital voucher, pound to cover the cost of the bottles and then an extra pound on top of the cost. “I just felt insulted, why should you just sit back and take that. “However, Aptamil UK have been amazing. They private messaged me on Instagram and said that they are looking into it for me. “They shouldn’t have to pick up the pieces after Tesco. Tesco has been approached for a comment.

title: john kinsella paul massey trial
story: NewsJohn Kinsella and Paul Massey trial: Gunman executed mob fixer "like in a film"Wendy Owen was terried when she watched John Kinsella being shot dead in front of her by a cyclist who hid his face, a court heardShareByNeil Docking:,  NOV NewsJohn Kinsella was shot and killed like in a film, Liverpool Crown Court heard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe girlfriend of an underworld figure watched in horror as a gunman executed him like in a film, a court heard. John Kinsella, , was shot four times by a masked cyclist while walking his dogs with Wendy Owen in St Helens. Prosecutors saya gangland feud lay behind his killing, and that of Salfords Mr Big Paul Massey, almost three years earlier. Liverpool Crown Court heard the two friends were caught up in a war between rival gangs, which pitted them against Mark Fellows and Steven Boyle - who are both accused of murdering the pair, reports the Liverpool Echo. The court heard Miss Owen was also shot at when an assassin struck on a country lane near the couples Rainhill home.   A video of her interview with police - just hours after the shooting at around .am on May  this year- was today played in court. They were walking six bulldogs along their usual route when Miss Owen said she heard the braking wheels of a mountain bike. She recalled hearing a puff noise, plus a shout or a raised voice, and initially thinking the cyclist wanted them to put their dogs on a lead. Miss Owen demonstrated how Kinsella staggered, assomething got him in the leg, and said she thought: Oh my God, he’s shooting at us. She said she screamed and approached the gunman, who turned to shoot at her. She said: I remember thinking he’s not stopping. Miss Owen said she ducked, then jumped over a fence to escape, shouted for help and flagged down a van on the M junction  slip road. Miss Owen said nothing was said by the shooter, or Kinsella, adding: I think he was in shock because he was getting attacked. She described looking back over the bushes and seeing the gunman move closer to Kinsella, then shoot him as he lay on the ground. Miss Owen said the weapon, which an officer told her may have been equipped with a silencer, sounded like a pellet gun.  The witness said the gunman was cool and only interested in her after she confronted him, before he ed to Kinsella. She said: He’s just gone forward again. As I’m replaying it in my mind, speaking about it, he’s wanted to keep, it’s like he wanted to finish the job. I know this sounds silly, but think of films, when they want to keep, it was like in a film when he wanted to finish the job and go. I thought bloody hell it’s like a film, he wants to finish what he’s doing. The jury heard a statement from a workman, who with a colleague found hysterical Miss Owen, then tried to help Kinsella. A police officer also spoke to her when she later ed to the scene in her Mercedes, after dropping off her bulldogs at home. He said: When questioned she said John was not in dispute with anyone or involved in drug supply. He bought and sold cars. [She said] he had been in prison about five years ago but was now behaving, as he didn’t want to go back there. She said he did have previous for armed robbery. The officer said he was later tasked with going to Miss Owens home to tell her Kinsella was dead. He said she came outside and said he’s dead, he’s dead isn’t he , to which he replied yes.  Miss Owen, who gave birth on Sunday, will be cross-examined later in the trial, via video link from a remote location. Firearms expert Andre Horn told the court Kinsella was shot twice from behind in the back, then twice in the back of the head. He said one round entered his lower back and exited through his chest, suggesting he was leaning forward, trying to dodge the bullet. Mr Horn said one went through his spine, so he would have collapsed, and three rounds were left lodged in his abdomen and head. He said the bullets indicated the assassin used a British-manufactured Webley revolver, which was last in service in the s. However, the expert said he did not find any of the bullets in the vast field which Miss Owens said were fired at her.

title: sick puppy eat dinner high
story: NewsSick puppy has to eat his dinner in a HIGH CHAIR so he doesnt starve to deathBuck the -month-old Labrador suffers from a rare condition called megaesophagus which means he could diehe doesnt eat sitting upShareCommentsByHayley Coyle:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video sick-dog-gets-high-chair-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA poorly dog with a rare medical condition can only eat out of a specially designed HIGH CHAIR. Buck, a -month-old Labrador, suffers from megaesophagus - which means he cannot eat food without being sick unless he is held in an upright position. So university boffins and an animal charity teamed up to create the unique contraption which holds the pooch in place so he can get down enough food. Buck currently weights just half of what he should and might have starved to death and not made it beyond his second birthdaythe high chair hadnt been invented. Buck was taken in by the charity Team Edward Labrador Rescue before his story was spotted by University of Nottingham vet and teaching associate, Emma Drinkall. Along with her partner Nick Rowan, a senior lecturer in product design and engineering at De Montford University, the couple designed and built the chair in just a day. The high chair has been designed so that Emma and Nick can continue to adapt it as Buck hopefully piles on the pounds. Buck has not regurgitated since using the chair and his carers have put him on a high calorie puppy food diet to help him improve his strength. Emma, from the University of Nottingham’s School of Veterinary Medicine and Science, said: “We saw the Buck’s story on social media, and I knew we just had to do somethinghe was going to have a chance. Luckily Nick and I have the combined expertise and experience to build the chair quickly. Heartwarming moment chimp saved from poachers hugs rescuer before being released There is currently no surgery available for dogs with this condition, and as Buck is already receiving the medications that can help, the one thing other thing that could help him keep his food down is gravity itself. Being upright while feeding will help the food drip through the sphincter that controls access to his stomach. Dogs with megaoesophagus are at risk of developing very serious chest infections which can prove fatal, because they can accidentally breathe in food particles when they regurgitate their food. We hope that by feeding Buck this way and stopping him from regurgitating we will minimise the risk of this additional complication developing. Wendy, Team Edward Labrador Rescue, David Bucks’ foster Dad, and Laura Buck’s Vet have all done an amazing job with Buck so far.” Nick said: “I’m just so pleased with how it fits, how comfortably he sits in it and how happy he is to be fed like this. He is the same width in his shoulders as our own  kilo Jack Russell, so without meeting Buck ourselves, we had to double check his measurements during the build – it just didn’t seem right for a big dog like a Labrador.” Cheeky dog caught sipping owners pint outside pub after checking coast is clearVet Laura Pearce, from the Lawrence Veterinary Centre in Eastwood, Notts., has been Buck’s vet since he was rescued by the charity. She said: “I am actually surprised that Buck has lived as long as he has with this condition. His oesophagus is abnormal in that it’s enlarged and has lost its tube-like state that pushes food through to the stomach. It means little of the food he eats actually makes it into his stomach for digestion, most gets stuck in pouches in the oesophagus or is regurgitated again.” Skeletal dog dumped by side of busy road was hours from deathBuck weighed only kg when he was taken in by the charity Team Edward Labrador Rescue which are based in Mansfield, Notts. Wendy Hopewell, who runs Team Edward, said: We were really shocked. The previous owner said they were really struggling to feed him but when I saw him I thought wow, Ive never seen a Labrador that thin before “It was just the most fabulous sight to see Buck eating in the chair and happy to be in it. To see how he sat in it straight away and get stuck in was incredible, it just pulls at your heartstrings.”

title: single mums tell how universal
story: NewsSingle mums tell how Universal Credit has plunged them into debtFour women have taken their fight over means-tested benefits to the High CourtShareByAmy-Clare Martin:,  NOV NewsFour women have taken their Universal Credit fight to the High Court "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSingle working mums fighting the Universal Credit chaos have told how the benefits shake-up has plunged them into debt and forced them to use foodbanks to feed their children. The four women who have taken their fight to the High Court rely on the means-tested handouts to top up their earnings. But fluctuating pay dates can mean two salary payments fall within one of the new system’s fixed monthly assessment periods, registering as double pay and wiping out that month’s benefit – leaving them unable to afford essentials. Care assistant Erin Barrett has had to use foodbanks repeatedly and twice tried to kill herself, judges heard. Katie Stewart had to quit her job to find one with a pay date which suits the new system. Voice of the Mirror: Sky high royal security fees put strain on tight UK budgetA third campaigner, dinner lady Danielle Johnson, was unable to pay her rent and forced into debt just to buy food. The fourth, occupational therapist Claire Woods, had to put her career on hold, went into debt and was forced to use a foodbank. She added: “I wanted to become free of welfare through my chosen profession but UC is holding me back from that.” The four are calling for a change in the “irrational and discriminatory” system. Solicitor Tessa Gregory, for Ms Johnson, said once UC is fully rolled out the issue will hit “tens of thousands,not more.” The Child Poverty Action Group’s lawyer Carla Clarke, representing the other women, called it “an injustice to hard-working parents”. Edward Brown, for Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd, said larger employers could change pay systems to suit UC. The DWP said claimants missing out one month “may” get more the next month.

title: stag lads chant back vegan
story: NewsStag do lads chant back at vegan activists who stormed steakhouse playing cow screamsGroom David Elvin was inside Touro Steakhouse in Brighton handcuffed to a dwarf dressed as an Oompa Loompa and led retaliation chantsShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video stag-do-chant-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA group of stag do lads chanted back at vegan activists who stormed a steakhouse playing cow screams. Groom David Elvin was inside the restaurant handcuffed to a dwarf dressed as an Oompa Loompa and led retaliation chants after jumping on a table. He and his hired dwarf encouraged his fellow revellers and other diners to chant stand upyou love meat and youre not singing any more. They were responding to protesters from Direct Action Everywhere, who stormed the Brighton restaurant waving anti-meat placards while playing recordings of cows being slaughtered. David, , was out with  of his pals on the night, reports The Sun . His friend Dan said: It was all a bit surreal.   Dave had just been handcuffed to a dwarf dressed as an Oompa Loompa - and the next thing these people rushed in with their placards and playing recordings of cows dying. Next thing our Oompa Loompa jumped up on the table and started shouting it at the top of his voice. “That was the cue for everyone  in the restaurant to join in. There are plenty of things that make up being a good friend - checking in with someone, asking how they are, sending them something they might like, buying them a boat….Small gestures can mean a lot to people who may be going through a tough time. The Mirror is working with Dave and CALM - the Campaign Against Living Miserably - to say be the mate you’d want. Ok, you can keep scrolling now.  Dan said the restaurant manager was grateful for the lads support, and even brought them a round of free drinks. While one activist gave a speech urging customers not to eat meat, the patrons of Touro Steakhouse, in Brighton, remained seemingly unbothered. And as protesters played a disturbing recording of animals allegedly being slaughtered, customers continued to chat.   The clip begins with protesters quietly walking into the restaurant whilst unsuspecting customers are eating their steaks. The person filming the video - who is a vegan - can be heard saying: “This smells horrible, look at all the flesh.” But as a spokeswoman attempts to give a speech about the benefits of veganism, patrons can be heard jeering and one mimics a cow mooing whilst waiters can be seen arguing with the protestors. Behind the camera, someone says “they’re letting us protest but they’re eating the flesh of animals in front of us”. The protesters remained in the popular steakhouse for  minutes before departing to stand outside. As they exit, the crowd of disgruntled meat eaters can be heard booing, whistling and chanting “youre not singing anymore” at the departing group. A spokeswoman for Direct Action Everywhere Brighton said: “In a time where we are experiencing mass environmental destruction, largely due to our unsustainable and unethical food choices, it is paramount that we put our egos and selfishness aside and accept that we are all connected, we are all animals.   “We can no longer ignore the suffering and pain we cause. We are not the only sentient beings that inhabit this planet.” Madsu Sudan Galtam, manager at Touro, said he called the police but they never attended the incident. The steakhouse offers customers an unlimited selection of sirloin steak, lamb, chicken, pork, with a salad and selection of cured meats for just pound.. It is estimated that the number of vegans in the UK has quadrupled to , since . Now direct action groups are on the rise as animal liberation activists team up with vegan protestors. Direct Action Everywhere have protested at a number of restaurants serving meat as well as supermarkets. The grassroots group, which was founded in the US in , now has five branches across Britain.

title: tiny fridge part blamed sparking
story: NewsTiny fridge part blamed for sparking Grenfell Tower infernoThe wire in the Hotpoint fridge-freezer is believed by experts to have overheated on Grenfells th floor, killing ShareCommentsByMatthew Young:,  NOV NewsAn inquiry has revealed the relay compressor compartment recovered from the fridge freezer from Flat  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the burnt out fridge part that started the killer Grenfell Tower inferno, investigators believe. A tiny wire connector in this Hotpoint fridge-freezer relay compressor is likely to have overheated in flat  on the fourth floor, the blaze inquiry was told. Electrical fire expert Dr John Glover highlighted “poor crimp connection”, which made the wires unsafe by failing to keep them tightly gripped. He said: “The overheating of the crimp starts the fire. It overheats, it glows, it ignites.” The inquiry previously heard that shyflat owner Behailu Kebede saw that smoke “seemed to be coming from his Hotpoint fridge-freezer”, calling  at .am. The blaze, on June , , spread quickly across the  floors of the West London tower block, killing .  Cabbie Mr Kebede, then , was one of three living in the flat. He banged on neighbours’ doors and waited for them to leave before fleeing himself, the hearing was told in the summer. The tower’s external cladding, feared to have fuelled the fire, is now banned. Investigators recovered the evidence from a small relay compressor compartment at the fridge-freezer’s bottom rear. The inquiry heard three inches of damaged wire found in one of the bedrooms  days later probably came from the same compartment. Dr Glover, engineer atshy shyinvestigators Failure Electrical, said poor crimping showed up in CT scans. “I found voids in  cross-sections indicating the crimp was not nice and tight.”  In a report for the inquiry Dr Glover concluded: “The overheating connector in my opinion was the first event that started burning the insulation on the wires that led to a short circuit.” This year, consumers were advised to carry on using the Hotpoint FFB after it was assessed as posing a “low risk” in an independent investigation. Whirlpool, which owns the brand, said its probe found the model showed no evidence of any fault and fully complied with all safety requirements. “We would like to reassure owners of these products that they are safe and they can continue to use them as normal,” the firm said in a statement. How Meghan Markles style has changed in her first  months in royal spotlight“All fridges, freezers, and fridge freezers across our UK brands – including Hotpoint, Indesit and shyWhirlpool – are manufactured with solid metal or aluminium laminate flame-retardant back .” Dr Glover said refrigerators made in the United States, which must have back casing of metallic steel, were safer than European models had to be.  “Instead of the plastic casing on the rear, which is combustible, contributing to the fire, you have a steel casing which is not,” he told the inquiry.

title: uks most prolific egg thief
story: NewsUKs most prolic egg thief jailed after being found with , rare specimensDaniel Lingham, , said he had been a silly man when he was arrested dressed head to toe in camouflage gear carrying a wooden catapult and binocularsShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video rspb-speak-out-egg-thief-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn obsessive man who illegally collected thousands of the UKs rarest bird eggs was jailed yesterday. Daniel Lingham, , dressed head to toe in camouflage gear before stealing the eggs from nature reserves. When police arrested him he was carrying a wooden catapult, binoculars and tree climbing “crampon-style” boots. He told officers: Ive been a silly man, havent I  A search of his home revealed over , eggs from rare birds including nightingales, woodlarks and kingfishers.  Chairman of the bench Darren Gilkes sentenced Lingham to  weeks in jail. Describing the defendants egg collecting obsession, Mr Gilkes said: “That is damaging for the whole community. They [the eggs] can never be recovered.” Norwich Magistrates Court heard that Lingham took the eggs from up to  locations across Norfolk. He was arrested by officers at Cawston Heath SSSI in May this year.  Officers found nine linnet eggs he said he had picked up from the ground. The rest of the eggs were discovered stashed in boxes throughout his home in Newton St Faith, Norfolk. The eggs were from  dferent birds,  of which were classed as “schedule one species”, meaning they were highly endangered. Prosecutor Colette Harper told magistrates the eggs could have been taken from up to  locations across Norfolk. At an earlier hearing, Lingham admitted five offences under the Wildle and Countryside Act. The court heard he was convicted of similar offences in  when he was sentenced to  weeks in prison for illegally collecting more than , eggs.  Mrs Harper described the egg collecting as “totally unnecessary and damaging”, causing “not only local but regional decline”. James Burrows, defending, said Lingham had been treated for his “obsessive compulsive disorder”, which was driving “an addiction to collecting wild bird eggs”. Mr Burrows said his client had “a dficult relation” with his father as a boy, adding: “The only way his father would give him praise washe collected rare eggs. “It has somewhat snowballed from there over all these years.”  Lingham was also handed a -year Criminal Behaviour Order banning him from committing similar crimes in the future. Mr Gilkes warned : “If you break this CBO, you could be put in custody for five years.” Mr Gilkes ordered the destruction of the catapult, binoculars and tree climbing boots. The court also heard the eggs would be given to the Natural History Museum.

title: woman who doctors thought pregnant
story: NewsWoman who doctors thought was pregnant had kg cyst the weight of seven newbornsEXCLUSIVE: Keely Favell, , from Swansea, carried an oian cyst so big she had dficulty breathingShareCommentsByRobin Eveleigh:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsKeely, , had a five-hour op to remove the growth "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Keely Favell’s swollen tum drew questions about baby due dates, she spared everyone embarrassment by playing along. Pregnancy tests had shown she was not expecting and she thought she was just piling on weight. Baffled about why her bump kept on growing, she made repeated visits to her doctor. But after more pregnancy tests came back negative her GP, still convinced a baby was the only explanation, referred her for an ultrasound scan. And it was then that her enormous bump was revealed to be an oian cyst weighing more than four stone – the same weight as seven newborn babies. Keely, , had a five-hour op to remove the growth – which she nicknamed Mr Whippy – and shed a third of her body weight. She says: “I lost sight of how dficult even simple things like driving a car or walking up the stairs had become. Losing my lump gave me my le back.” Keely noticed she was gaining weight around  but thought nothing of it. “I’ve always been chunky but over a couple of years I gradually got this tummy” she says.  “I couldn’t understand it. I was exercising and eating healthily but I was slowly getting bigger. It crept up so slowly I didn’t know anything was wrong – I thought I was putting on timber.” Keely, who has been with partner Jamie Gibbins for  years, thought she could be expecting. “We did wonder a few timesI was pregnant” she says, “but we did at least three home tests and they ruled it out.” Assuming it was simple weight gain – which had made her balloon from a size  to a , weighing in at  stone – Keely carried on as normal. Then, in the summer of , she blacked out at her office admin job and decided to see her GP. “It was a tough period in work and when I passed out my GP put it down to stress,” she says. “My blood tests came back clear and when I fainted again, I was told it was probably a side effect of acne tablets I’d been prescribed. But I’d stopped taking them six months previously.  “I pointed to my belly and said, ‘Could it be anything to do with this ’” Keely, from Swansea, says her GP insisted she must be pregnant, despite blood tests ruling this out. Convinced there had been a mistake, a new blood test was requested. She says: “Anyone would have thought I was nine months gone. It wasn’t the first time I’d been mistaken for an expectant mum but my GP had the test results. “People had seen me waddling around, carrying this lump, and I’d been asked a few times when I was due. It was so embarrassing trying to explain I was – or so I thought – just fat. I’d go along with it to spare everyone’s blushes. I remember trying to shop for clothes in December  and nothing would fit. I was skin and bone on top, then this massive lump and normal legs. The only thing that was going to fit was maternity wear.”   She ed to her GP that month to discuss her blood test results – again negative for pregnancy. Still convinced Keely was expecting, her GP referred her for an ultrasound scan. There, Keely was presented with an ominous black screen. “By the time I had the appointment it was January last year” she says. “I had Jamie beside me as the radiologist moved the probe over my tummy. I saw her eyes widen in horror but the screen was blank. The look on her face said it all. When she said she had to get a consultant I started to panic. Jamie did his best to reassure me but I felt shyparalysed with fear.” The consultant sent Keely for an emergency CT scan – which revealed a cyst surrounded by fluid. “He told me I wasn’t fat all, I was quite thin. But I had a cm-thick sac of fluid in my belly.”  Hop on your bike or in the pool to age slower - and keep out the weights room Keely was referred to a high-risk obstetrics consultant and examined in February. “By this time, even walking was a struggle and I had dficulty breathing,” she says. “I’ll never forget the look of shock on his face when the consultant examined me. He said I had a large oian mass and the only option was surgery. He couldn’t say what it was exactly, or how big. He warned me there might be more than one and they could be attached to other organs. “Agreeing to the surgery, I felt like I was signing my le away. Until they opened me up, no one knew what they would find.” As Keely waited four weeks for surgery, her stomach swelled another in. She finally went under the kne at Swansea’s Singleton Hospital in March last year. What she hoped would be a routine hour-long op ran for five hours as her surgeon removed a cyst weighing kg – or st lb. With newborns averaging lb oz, Keely’s benign cyst weighed the same as septuplets. She said: “I remember still being groggy from the anaesthetic as they wheeled me back to the ward and excited hospital staff were shoving photos in front of me.  “I didn’t understand why until I came round and everyone was treating me like a minor celebrity. They explained how big this cyst was and showed me pictures – I couldn’t believe I’d been walking around carrying this medical alien. “It looked like a massive pile of ice cream so I called it Mr Whippy!” Keely has a cm scar from her sternum to her pelvis but was back on her feet soon after the op. She says: “I was sore but walking around felt amazing!” Keely lost her right oy in the surgery but medics say her odds of becoming a mum are unaffected. In the meantime, she is getting used to one unwanted side-effect of pregnancy all new mums dread. “At  and even though I’ve never been pregnant, I’ve been left with stretch marks,” she says.

title: childs toy torch waters edge
story: NewsChilds toy and torch by waters edge led police to find bodies of mum and boyThe bodies of Emma Sillett, , and her son, Jenson Spellman, five, were recovered from the Valehouse reservoir, Derbyshire, two days after they went missingShareCommentsByElaine McCahillEugene Henderson:,  NOV NewsA childs cuddly toy and torch led police to find the bodies of Jason Spellman, five, and his mum Emma Sillett "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA childs cuddly toy and torch found by the waters edge led police to find the bodies of boy, five, and his mum in a reservoir, an inquest heard. Social worker Emma Sillett and her son Jenson Spellman had been missing for two days when police ers recovered their bodies from the man made lake. Emma Sillett, , and her son, Jenson Spellman, were last seen at a McDonalds restaurant near their home in Glossop, Dersbyshire, at lunchtime on November . Jensons father John Spellmen raised the alarm after his partner and child failed tohome that evening.  Chesterfield Coroners Court heard officers found Ms Silletts black Peugeot  at the Valehouse reservoir, near Tintwhistle, Derbyshire the following day. A search of the area found the cuddly toy and childs torch by the waters edge, but as darkness fell the search was called off. A specialist underwater team discovered the two bodies when they ed to the scene the next day. The reservoir is less than three miles from the home Emma shared with John and their little boy in the village of Dinting, near Glossop, Derbys. Detective Chief Inspector Sally Blaiklock told the opening of the inquests into the deaths that Ms Sillett, , and Jenson were captured on CCTV leaving the house at .am on November .  But Jenson did not make it to Simmondley Primary School in Glossop, instead he was caught on CCTV at a McDonalds in Hattersley, just a few miles from her home that lunchtime. The mother and son stayed for an hour before driving off. Neither were seen alive again. Concerned when they did nothome Mr Spellman eventually rang  at .pm and reported both as missing. Police spoke to him again the next day and the information he gave them led officers to the deserted reservoir high up on the edge of the Peak District. DCI Blaiklock said her vehicle was found in an unofficial car park normally used by workers from United Utilities. Items were found which were thought to belong to Emma and Jenson, including a torch and a cuddly toy, at the waters edge, said DCI Blaikman.  The next day a specialist team arrive at am and at am the underwater search unit found two bodies in the water. Post mortems carried out by Dr Stuart Hamilton at Leicester Royal Infirmary gave the preliminary cause of death as drowning. No other injuries were found on either body. Detectives have said they are not looking for anyone  in connection with the deaths. Derbyshire Senior Coroner Dr Robert Hunter adjourned the inquests pending the results of toxicology tests being carried out and further police investigations. The inquest heard that Ms Sillett worked for Stockport Borough Councils social services department in their adoption team.  Neighbours living near to the familys three bedroom semi-detached house described the couple and their son as a a great family. But friends said the mother had recently been dealing with underlying problems in her le. When she was reported missing many took to social media urging her to contact them. After the tragedy Jensons headteacher at Simmondley Primary School in Glossop, paid tribute to a perfect child Debbie Greaves said everyone at the school was devastated by the sad news. Describing him as a bundle of energy she added: He constantly had a beaming, infectious smile and was kind and caring.

title: el chapo cartel mastermind revealed
story: NewsEl Chapo cartel mastermind revealed as ghost crime boss who has NEVER been locked upEXCLUSIVE Despite police catching world renowned crime lord El Chapo, bloodshed is increasing and new face is thought to be responsibleShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news us-news video watch-how-security-working-el-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter hunting the world’s most powerful drug trafficker for more than  years, US law enforcement officers were jubilant when they finally got their hands on Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman. The US Drug Enforcement Administration and local marines finally recaptured the -year-old crime lord, who twice escaped from prison, in his native Mexico in . But now – while El Chapo is standing trial in New York and allegations surface that he bribed Mexico City’s chief of police – authorities have discovered that another, even more powerful, kingpin was the true mastermind behind the Sinaloa cartel. It now appears that El Chapo was something of a public face, the poster boy for the world’s most feared drugs cartel. The real leader of the trafficking operation is El Chapo’s former partner, -year-old Ismael Zambada, known as El Mayo. For, despite El Chapo’s incarceration, analysts have seen an increase in the cartel’s shipments to the States, including the highly addictive, often fatal, drug fentanyl.  The bloodshed has also escalated under El Mayo’s command. Murders in Mexico rose % in the first half of this year, to ,, up from , in the same period in . Authorities have attributed the rise in deaths to battles between the rival Jalisco New Generation drugs cartel and El Mayo’s organisation, for control of trafficking routes from Mexico’s west coast to America. But while Sinaloa’s activity has escalated under El Mayo’s reign, he remains a ghost. Whereas El Chapo’s love of the limelight and lavish lestyle eventually led to his demise, El Mayo, a former poppy field worker, has stayed below the radar. He tops the DEA’s list of the world’s most wanted criminals, with a poundmillion bounty on his head, but the multibillionaire has never been in prison, despite more than  years of trafficking. Former chief of operations at the DEA, Jack Riley, who captured El Chapo, says he has no doubt who Sinaloa’s real boss is. He says: “Mayo is the most powerful drug trafficker. I even think we have underestimated his influence and power in controlling the US drug market.”  Thousands of Mexican marines, police and DEA agents – all supported by drones and high-tech surveillance – have searched for El Mayo for more than  decades. But he is still the most elusive fugitive on the planet. To evade capture, he has had plastic surgery, wears a range of disguises, and never sleeps in the same place twice. He remains in constant movement, especially in the mountainous region shared by the states of Durango, Sinaloa and Chihuahua, in northwest Mexico. The area is known as the Golden Triangle, thanks to its abundance of poppies and marijuana. But the biggest weapons in El Mayo’s evasion arsenal are the hundreds of officials he pays off. They, according to El Chapo’s defence team, stretch to the very highest office in Mexico, with El Mayo allegedly paying pound.million to President Enrique Pena Nieto, who has denied the allegation. El Chapo’s defence lawyer, Jeffrey Lichtman, told jurors: “He’s [Guzman] blamed for being the leader, while the real leaders are living freely and openly in Mexico.”In truth, he controlled nothing. Mayo Zambada did. Mayo Zambada kept paying the Mexican government, president after president, two in a row – and somehow he remains free. And who is the one that’s constantly being hunted down  It’s Guzman.   “[Government officials] were paid off to leave Zambada alone.” Former Mexican president Felipe Calderon, who preceded Neito, has always denied taking cartel money. El Mayo started working with a cartel based in Juarez, on the Mexico-US border, in the s and s. When Juarez’s leader, Amado Carrillo Fuentes, died in  after botched plastic surgery to change his face, the cartel eventually split into two factions. One gang was based in Tijuana, on the US border, and the other, set up largely by El Mayo and El Chapo, was in Sinaloa, further south. When the Tijuana cartel began to decline, and the pair took advantage. They set out to expand their trafficking routes to the US and Europe, as they controlled much of the heroin production and shipment in Mexico. The Sinaloa cartel went on to build a poundbillion-a-year international cocaine, heroin and human-trafficking empire. El Mayo’s strength was his ability to quickly adapt to customers’ demands.   And, as the cash poured in, his army of highly educated money men laundered their ill-gotten gains through some of the world’s biggest banks and offshore accounts, while also investing in legitimate companies. Mike Vigil, former head of international operations at the DEA, explained: “He has a very ersied portfolio. Even though he’s only had maybe an elementary school education, he’s received a Hard-level education from some of the most prolic, knowledgeable and astute drug lords that Mexico has ever had.” Now, despite his advancing years, growing frailty, and battle with diabetes, EL Mayo is as sharp as ever. Since El Chapo’s arrest in January , he has successfully ersied the cartel’s business, from cannabis and coke to deadly fentanyl, an opioid-based synthetic drug. The average revenue from one kilo of fentanyl purchased in China can yield as much as  times the income of one kilo of heroin bought in Colombia, according to the DEA. And now, with America in the grip of an opioid crisis, the Sinaloa cartel’s supply shows no sign of slowing.   According to US agencies, El Mayo tends to act more as an entrepreneur than as a drug lord. The Office of Foreign Assets Control of the United States says he has been in charge of many financial operations within the Sinaloa cartel. And he uses his considerable resources to pay for protection from the authorities, and within the mountain communities where he hides out. Indeed, El Mayo has often become a patron and protector of locals in the area. Unlike other drug barons, he is not known for targeting civilians. This – and the fact that his businesses offer them employment, security and health care services not covered by local authorities – has allowed him to build an impenetrable protection network. Francisco Jimenez Reynoso, a researcher at the University of Guadalajara, says: “They buy wills, they buy loyalties and, in many cases, they are willing to give up their lives for a character of this nature, eventhey engage in illicit activities.”  Despite his low-key, almost gentle, persona, El Mayo is not a man to be crossed. Protected by dozens of henchmen, he has stayed at the top despite huge blows to his inner circle. In recent years, two of his sons and a nephew have been captured. But his most signicant loss was his bother, Jesus Zambada, who was arrested in  and is now helping the US’s case against El Chapo. After seeking a deal with US prosecutors, Jesus – the cartel’s chief accountant for more than  years – said his brother and El Chapo were considered Sinaloa’s leaders. El Mayo also lost his right-hand man, Manuel Torres Felix, in a shootout with the military in . Five years later, El Mayo survived an attack, reportedly by Damaso Lopez Nunez, another Sinaloa leader. A slew of deaths followed the assassination attempt. The ambush also targeted two of El Chapo’s sons, suggesting an internal power struggle after his capture in Mexico in , and his extradition to the US a year later. Some analysts had believed El Mayo might be slipping into the shadows, or even retiring, but instead, since El Chapo’s capture, he seems to be relishing his sole command.
